acus: <entryFree id="n649" type="main" key="a^cus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>cf. 2. acer</etym>. <sense id="n649.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A needle</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pin</hi>, as being <hi rend="ital">pointed</hi>, both for common use and ornament:“quasarcinatrix veletiam ornatrix utitur,” Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=9" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 9</bibl> Müll. </sense><sense id="n649.1" n="A" level="2"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">mirabar vulnus, quod acu punctum videtur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:chapter=24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mil. 24</bibl></cit>.—Hence, acu pingere, <hi rend="ital">to embroider</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:582" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 582</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:6:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 6, 23</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:48:section=191" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 48, § 191</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 19, 22, 22</bibl>.—Esp. <hi rend="ital">a hair-pin</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">figat acus tortas sustineatque comas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:14:24" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 14, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">foramen acūs,</quote> <trans><tr>the eye of a needle</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:19:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 19, 24</bibl></cit>.—Also, <hi rend="ital">a surgeon's needle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a probe</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:7:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 7, 17</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n649.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: acu rem tangere, <hi rend="ital">to touch the thing with a needle;</hi> in Engl. phrase, <hi rend="ital">to hit the nail on the head</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:5:2:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 5, 2, 19</bibl>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">to denote careful and successful effort: si acum quaereres, acum invenisses,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:2:1:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. 2, 1, 13</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n649.3" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The tongue of a buckle</hi>, Treb. Poll. <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> 14</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n649.4" n="III" level="1"> I. q. acus, ĕris, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:2:10:40" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 2, 10, 40</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n649.5" n="IV" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An implement of husbandry</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 1, 43, 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n650" type="main" key="a^cus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcus</orth>, <itype>ĕris</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> (also, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, v. 1. acus, III.) [kindred with acus, ūs, Goth. <sense id="n650.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">ahana</hi>, old Norse <hi rend="ital">agn</hi>, old Germ. <hi rend="ital">Agana</hi>], = <foreign lang="greek">a)/xuron</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">the husk of grain and of pulse; chaff</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 54, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:52" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 52</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:57" default="NO">57</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:3:9:8" default="NO">3, 9, 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n651" type="main" key="a^cus3" n="3"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>1. acus</etym>, <sense id="n651.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kind of sea-fish with a pointed snout</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the hornpike</hi> or <hi rend="ital">gar-pike</hi> (Gr. <foreign lang="greek">belo/nh</foreign>): <cit><quote lang="la">acus sive belone unus piscium, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:166" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 9, 51, 76, § 166</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">et satius tenues ducere credis acos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:10:37:6" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 10, 37, 6</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:32:145" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 32, 11, 53, § 145</bibl>, where <hi rend="ital">belonae</hi> again occurs. (Some read <hi rend="ital">una</hi> for <hi rend="ital">unus</hi> in the passage from Plin., and <hi rend="ital">acūs</hi> for <hi rend="ital">acos</hi> in Mart., as if these forms belonged to 1. acus.)</sense></entryFree>
acusilas: <entryFree id="n652" type="main" key="A^cu_si^las"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăcūsĭlas</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>from <foreign lang="greek">*)akousi/laos</foreign></etym>, <sense id="n652.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an Argive historian</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:12:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 12, 53</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acutalis: <entryFree id="n653" type="main" key="a^cu_ta_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcūtālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>acutus</etym>, <sense id="n653.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pointed</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">terminus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1245,001:Col. p. 132" default="NO"><author>Front.</author> Col. p. 132</bibl></cit> Goes.</sense></entryFree>
acutarus: <entryFree id="n654" type="main" key="a^cu_ta_rus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcūtārus</orth> (for <sense id="n654.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">acutarius</hi>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <hi rend="ital">that sharpens instruments</hi>: acutarus taber, Ins. ap. Henzen. 7216.</sense></entryFree>
acutatus: <entryFree id="n655" type="main" key="a^cu_ta_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcūtātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n655.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">sharpened</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">sagittæ,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> 1, 22, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
acute: <entryFree id="n656" type="main" key="a^cu_te"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcūte</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. acuo, <sense id="n656.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">P. a. fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
acutor: <entryFree id="n657" type="main" key="a^cu_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcūtor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>acuo</etym>, <sense id="n657.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one that sharpens</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a sharpener</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Not. Tir.</author> p. 120</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acutule: <entryFree id="n658" type="main" key="a^cu_tu^le"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcūtŭle</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, see the foll. art. <sense id="n658.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
acutulus: <entryFree id="n659" type="main" key="a^cu_tu^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcūtŭlus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <sense id="n659.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj. dim.</hi> [acutus], <hi rend="ital">somewhat pointed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">acute</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">subtile</hi>: conclusiones, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:7:18" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 7, 18</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">doctores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:17:5" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 17, 5</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcūtŭle</orth>, <hi rend="ital">somewhat sharply</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Conf. 3:7" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Conf. 3, 7</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acutum: <entryFree id="n660" type="main" key="a^cu_tum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcūtum</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. <itype>acuo</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos></entryFree>
acutus: <entryFree id="n661" type="main" key="a^cu_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcūtus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, v. <itype>acuo</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos></entryFree>
acva: <entryFree id="n662" type="main" key="acva"><orth extent="full" lang="la">acva</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">acvarivs</orth>, in Inscrr. for aqua and aquarius.</entryFree>
acylos: <entryFree id="n663" type="greek" key="a^cy^los"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcylos</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/kulos</foreign>, <sense id="n663.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the acorn of the holm-oak</hi> (ilex), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 6, 8, § 19</bibl> (cf. Hom. Od. 10, 242).</sense></entryFree>
acyrologia: <entryFree id="n664" type="greek" key="a^cy_ro^lo^gi^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcȳrŏlŏgĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)kurologi/a</foreign>, in rhetoric, <sense id="n664.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an impropriety of speech;</hi> e. g.: <cit><quote lang="la">sperare for timere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 4, 419</bibl></cit> (in pure Lat. <hi rend="ital">improprium</hi> or <hi rend="ital">impropria dictio</hi> is used instead of it: (quod proprietati est contrarium) id apud nos <hi rend="ital">improprium</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">a)/kuron</foreign> apud Graecos vocatur; quale est <hi rend="ital">tantum sperare dolorem</hi>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:2:3" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 8, 2, 3</bibl>; cf. Don. ap. Lind. Corp. Gr. 1, 28; <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 242</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> 2, p. 444</bibl>).</sense></entryFree>
ad: <entryFree id="n665" type="main" key="ad"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad</orth>, <pos>prep.</pos> with <case>acc.</case> (from the fourth century after Christ written also <orth extent="full" lang="la">at</orth>; Etrusc. suf. -a; Osc. az; Umbr. and Old Lat. ar, as <pb n="27" /> <cb n="AD" /> in Eug. Tab., in S. C. de Bacch., as arveho for adveho; arfuerunt, arfuisse, for adfuerunt, etc.; arbiter for adbiter; so, ar me advenias, Plant. Truc. 2, 2, 17; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 559</bibl> P.; Vel. Long. 2232 P.; Fabretti, Glos. Ital. col. 5) [cf. Sanscr. adhi; Goth. and Eng. at; Celt. pref. ar, as armor, i.e. ad mare; Rom. a].<sense id="n665.0" n="I" level="1"> As antith. to <hi rend="ital">ab</hi> (as <hi rend="ital">in</hi> to <hi rend="ital">ex</hi>), in a progressive order of relation, ad denotes, first, the direction toward an object; then the reaching of or attaining to it; and finally, the being at or near it.</sense><sense id="n665.1" n="A" level="2"> In space. </sense><sense id="n665.2" n="1" level="3"> Direction toward, <hi rend="ital">to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">toward</hi>, and first, </sense><sense id="n665.3" n="a" level="4"> Horizontally: <cit><quote lang="la">fugere ad puppim colles campique videntur,</quote> <trans><tr>the hills and fields appear to fly toward the ship</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:390" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 390</bibl></cit>: meridie umbrae cadunt ad septentrionem, ortu vero ad occasum, <hi rend="ital">to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">toward the north and west</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 13</bibl>, and so often of the geog. position of a place in reference to the points of compass, with the verbs <hi rend="ital">jacere</hi>, <hi rend="ital">vergere</hi>, <hi rend="ital">spectare</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">Asia jacet ad meridiem et austrum, Europa ad septentriones et aquiionem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=31" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 31</bibl></cit> Müll.; <cit><quote lang="la">and in Plin. very freq.: Creta ad austrum ... ad septentrionem versa, 4, 20: ad Atticam vergente, 4, 21 al.—Also trop.: animus alius ad alia vitia propensior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:37:81" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 37, 81</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n665.4" n="b" level="4"> In a direction upwards (esp. in the poets, very freq.): manusque sursum ad caelum sustulit, Naev. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 116, 30</bibl> (B. Pun. p. 13, ed. Vahl.): manus ad caeli templa tendebam lacrimans, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:20:40" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 20, 40</bibl> (Ann. v. 50 ed. Vahl.); cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">duplices tendens ad sidera palmas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:93" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 93</bibl></cit>: molem ex profundo saxeam ad caelum vomit, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 1325</bibl> P.: clamor ad caelum volvendus, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 7:section=104" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 7, § 104</bibl> Müll. (Ann. v. 520 ed. Vahl.) (cf. with this: tollitur in caelum clamor, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 6, 1</bibl>, or Ann. v. 422): <cit><quote lang="la">ad caelumque ferat flammai fulgura rursum, of Aetna,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:725" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 725</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:191" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 191</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:325" default="NO" valid="yes">2, 325</bibl>: sidera sola micant; <cit><quote lang="la">ad quae sua bracchia tendens, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:188" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 188</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">altitudo pertingit ad caelum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,056:4:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Dan. 4, 17</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n665.5" n="c" level="4"> Also in the direction downwards (for the usu. <hi rend="ital">in</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">tardiore semper ad terras omnium quae geruntur in caelo effectu cadente quam visu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:216" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 97, 99, § 216</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n665.6" n="2" level="3"> The point or goal at which any thing arrives. </sense><sense id="n665.7" n="a" level="4"> Without reference to the space traversed in passing, <hi rend="ital">to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">toward</hi> (the most common use of this prep.): cum stupro redire ad suos popularīs, Naev. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=317" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 317</bibl> Müll. (B. Pun. p. 14 ed. Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">ut ex tam alto dignitatis gradu ad superos videatur potius quam ad inferos pervenisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:3:12" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 3, 12</bibl></cit>: ad terras decidat aether, Lucan. 2, 58. —Hence, </sense><sense id="n665.8" n="(a)" level="5"> With verbs which designate going, coming, moving, bearing, bringing near, adapting, taking, receiving, calling, exciting, admonishing, etc., when the verb is compounded with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> the prep. is not always repeated, but the constr. with the <case>dat.</case> or <case>acc.</case> employed; cf. Rudd. II. pp. 154, 175 n. (In the ante-class. per., and even in Cic., <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> is generally repeated with most verbs, as, ad eos accedit, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sex. Rosc. 8</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad Sullam adire,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad se adferre,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 4, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">reticulum ad narīs sibi admovebat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad laborem adhortantur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> de Sen. 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">T. Vectium ad se arcessit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:114" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 5, 114</bibl></cit>; but the poets of the Aug. per., and the historians, esp. Tac., prefer the dative; also, when the compound verb contains merely the idea of approach, the constr. with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> and the <case>acc.</case> is employed; but when it designates increase, that with the <case>dat.</case> is more usual: accedit ad urbem, <hi rend="ital">he approaches the city;</hi> but, accedit provinciae, <hi rend="ital">it is added to the province.</hi>）— </sense><sense id="n665.9" n="(b)" level="5"> Ad me, te, se, for domum meam, tuam, suam (in Plaut. and Ter. very freq.): <cit><quote lang="la">oratus sum venire ad te huc,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:5:1:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 5, 1, 12</bibl></cit>: spectatores plaudite atque ite ad vos comissatum, id. Stich. <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">eamus ad me,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:3:5:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 3, 5, 64</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ancillas traduce huc ad vos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:4:4:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 4, 4, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">transeundumst tibi ad Menedemum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> 4, 4, 17</bibl></cit>: intro nos vocat ad sese, tenet intus apud se, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 86</bibl> P.: <cit><quote lang="la">te oro, ut ad me Vibonem statim venias,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:3:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 3, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">16, 10 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n665.10" n="(g)" level="5"> Ad, with the name of a deity in the <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>, is elliptical for ad templum or aedem (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">Thespiadas, quae ad aedem Felicitatis sunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 4, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 2, 35</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">in aedem Veneris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:1:2:120" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 1, 2, 120</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">in aedem Concordiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 3, 9</bibl></cit>, <cb n="AD" /> 21; <cit><quote lang="la">2, 6, 12): ad Dianae,</quote> <trans><tr>to the temple of</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:4:2:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 4, 2, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad Opis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:8:1:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 8, 1, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad Castoris,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Quint. 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad Juturnae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=101" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 101</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad Vestae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:9:35 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 9, 35 al.</bibl></cit>: cf. Rudd. II. p. 41, n. 4, and p. 334.—</sense><sense id="n665.11" n="(d)" level="5"> With verbs which denote a giving, sending, informing, submitting, etc., it is used for the simple <case>dat.</case> (Rudd. II. p. 175): litteras dare <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> aliquem, <hi rend="ital">to send</hi> or <hi rend="ital">write one a letter;</hi> and: litteras dare <hi rend="ital">alicui</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to give a letter to one;</hi> hence Cic. never says, like Caesar and Sall., alicui scribere, which strictly means, <hi rend="ital">to write for one</hi> (as a receipt, etc.), but always mittere, scribere, perscribere <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> aliquem: <cit><quote lang="la">postea ad pistores dabo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:3:3:119" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 3, 3, 119</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praecipe quae ad patrem vis nuntiari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:2:2:109" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. 2, 2, 109</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in servitutem pauperem ad divitem dare,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ter.</author> Ph. 4, 3, 48</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nam ad me Publ. Valerius scripsit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:14:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 14, 2 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">de meis rebus ad Lollium perscripsi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">velim domum ad te scribas, ut mihi tui libri pateant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:4:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 4, 14</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 16</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad primam (sc. epistulam) tibi hoc scribo,</quote> <trans><tr>in answer to your first</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 15, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad Q. Fulvium Cons. Hirpini et Lucani dediderunt sese,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:15:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 27, 15, 1</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:22:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 28, 22, 5</bibl>.—Hence the phrase: mittere or scribere librum ad aliquem, <hi rend="ital">to dedicate a book to one</hi> (Greek, <foreign lang="greek">prosfwnei=n</foreign>): <cit><quote lang="la">has res ad te scriptas, Luci, misimus, Aeli,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0043,001:Sat. 1" default="NO"><author>Lucil.</author> Sat. 1</bibl></cit>, ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 4, 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae institueram, ad te mittam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:3:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 3, 5</bibl></cit>: ego interea admonitu tuo perfeci sane argutulos libros ad Varronem; <cit><quote lang="la">and soon after: mihi explices velim, maneasne in sententia, ut mittam ad eum quae scripsi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 13, 18</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:1:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 1, 19</bibl>.—So in titles of books: M. Tullii Ciceronis ad Marcum Brutum Orator; M. T. Cic. ad Q. Fratrem Dialogi tres de Oratore, etc.—In the titles of odes and epigrams <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> aliquem signifies <hi rend="ital">to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">addressed to.</hi>—（<foreign lang="greek">e</foreign>) With names of towns after verbs of motion, ad is used in answer to the question Whither? instead of the simple <hi rend="ital">acc.;</hi> but commonly with this difference, that ad denotes <hi rend="ital">to the vicinity of</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the neighborhood of</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">miles ad Capuam profectus sum, quintoque anno post ad Tarentum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> de Sen. 4, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:81" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 3, 81</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad Veios,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 19</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:14:18" default="NO" valid="yes">14, 18</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:40 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. C. 3, 40 al.</bibl>—Ad is regularly used when the proper name has an appellative in apposition to it: <cit><quote lang="la">ad Cirtam oppidum iter constituunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 81:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 81, 2</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:3:1:22" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 3, 1, 22</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:9:9" default="NO">4, 9, 9</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">or when it is joined with usque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:34:section=87" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 34, § 87</bibl></cit>; id. Deiot, 7, 19.— (When an adjective is added, the simple <case>acc.</case> is used <usg type="style">poet.</usg>, as well as with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">magnum iter ad doctas proficisci cogor Athenas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:21:1" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3, 21, 1</bibl></cit>; the simple <case>acc.</case>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:2:83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 2, 83</bibl>: doctas jam nunc eat, inquit, Athenas).—（<foreign lang="greek">z</foreign>) With verbs which imply a hostile movement toward, or protection in respect to any thing, <hi rend="ital">against</hi> = adversus: <cit><quote lang="la">nonne ad senem aliquam fabricam fingit?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:3:2:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 3, 2, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Lernaeas pugnet ad hydras,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:19:9" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3, 19, 9</bibl></cit>: neque quo pacto fallam, nec quem dolum ad eum aut machinam commoliar, old poet in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:29:73" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 29, 73</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Belgarum copias ad se venire vidit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">7, 70</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ipse ad hostem vehitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,014:4:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Dat. 4, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Dion. 5:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Dion. 5, 4</bibl>: Romulus ad regem impetus facit (a phrase in which <hi rend="ital">in</hi> is commonly found), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:5:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 5, 7</bibl>, and 44, 3, 10: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem ad hostem ducere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 52</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">clipeos ad tela protecti obiciunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:443" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 443</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">munio me ad haec tempora,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad hos omnes casus provisa erant praesidia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 65</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">7, 41</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">so with nouns: medicamentum ad aquam intercutem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:24" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">remedium ad tertianam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> Sat. 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">munimen ad imbrīs,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:352" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 352</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">farina cum melle ad tussim siccam efficasissima est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:243" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 20, 22, 89, § 243</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad muliebre ingenium efficaces preces,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:19" default="NO" valid="yes">1, 19</bibl> (in these two passages <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> may have the force of <hi rend="ital">apud</hi>, Hand).—（<foreign lang="greek">h</foreign>) The repetition of <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> to denote the direction to a place and to a person present in it is rare: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc tu abi ad forum ad herum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:2:2:100" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 2, 2, 100</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">vocatis classico ad concilium militibus ad tribunos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5</bibl></cit> 47.—(The distinction between <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> and <hi rend="ital">in</hi> is given by <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> 409</bibl> P., thus: <hi rend="ital">in</hi> forum ire est in ipsum forum intrare; <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> forum autem ire, in locum foro proximum; ut <hi rend="ital">in</hi> tribunal et <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> tribunal venire non unum est; quia ad tribunal venit litigator, in tribunal vero praetor aut judex; cf. also <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 73:14" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 73, 14</bibl>, deus ad homines venit, immo, <cb n="AD" /> quod propius est, in homines venit.)—</sense><sense id="n665.12" n="b" level="4"> The terminus, with ref. to the space traversed, <hi rend="ital">to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">even to</hi>, with or without <hi rend="ital">usque</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:7:16" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 10, 7, 16</bibl>: ingurgitavit usque ad imum gutturem, Naev. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 207, 20</bibl> (R<bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Com. Rel. p. 30</bibl>): dictator pervehitur usque ad oppidum, Naev. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=153" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 153</bibl> Müll. (B. Pun. p. 16 ed. Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">via pejor ad usque Baii moenia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:5:96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 5, 96</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 1, 97</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">rigidum permanat frigus ad ossa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:355" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 355</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:969" default="NO" valid="yes">1, 969</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum sudor ad imos Manaret talos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:9:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 9, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut quantum posset, agmen ad mare extenderet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:3:9:10" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 3, 9, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">laeva pars ad pectus est nuda,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:6:5:27 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 6, 5, 27 al.</bibl></cit>—Hence the Plinian expression, petere aliquid (usque) ad aliquem, <hi rend="ital">to seek something everywhere</hi>, <hi rend="ital">even with one</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut ad Aethiopas usque peteretur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 6, 9, § 51</bibl></cit> (where Jan now reads ab Aethiopia); so, <cit><quote lang="la">vestīs ad Seras peti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 12, 1, 1</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">si quid poscam, usque ad ravim poscam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:5:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 2, 5, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">deverberāsse usque ad necem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:2:2:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 2, 2, 13</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">without usque: hic ad incitas redactus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:4:136" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 4, 136</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">4, 2, 52</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:4:2:85" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Poen. 4, 2, 85</bibl>; illud ad incitas cum redit atque internecionem, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 123, 20</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">virgis ad necem caedi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:29:section=70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 29, § 70</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:2:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 2, 42</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:38:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 24, 38, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:11:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 11, 37</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:26" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 26</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=dom.:8 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Dom. 8 al.</bibl></sense><sense id="n665.13" n="3" level="3"> Nearness or proximity in gen. = apud, <hi rend="ital">near to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">by</hi>, <hi rend="ital">at</hi>, <hi rend="ital">close by</hi> (in anteclass. per. very freq.; not rare later, esp. in the historians): pendent peniculamenta unum ad quemque pedum, <hi rend="ital">trains are suspended at each foot</hi>, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 149, 33</bibl> (Ann. v. 363 ed. Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">ut in servitute hic ad suum maneat patrem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:prol. 49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. prol. 49</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 3, 98</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">3, 5, 41: sol quasi flagitator astat usque ad ostium,</quote> <trans><tr>stands like a creditor continually at the door</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:3:2:81" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 3, 2, 81</bibl></cit> (cf. with same force, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 522, 25</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">apud ipsum astas): ad forīs adsistere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:chapter=66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 1, 66</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,016:chapter=24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Arch. 24</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">astiterunt ad januam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:10:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Act. 10, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non adest ad exercitum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:3:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 3, 6</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> prol. 133</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aderant ad spectaculum istud,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,003:23:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Luc. 23, 48</bibl></cit>: has (testas) e fenestris in caput Deiciunt, qui prope ad ostium adspiraverunt, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 288, 31</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">et nec opinanti Mors ad caput adstitit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:959" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 959</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod Romanis ad manum domi supplementum esset,</quote> <trans><tr>at hand</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:19:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 9, 19, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec arma habere ad manum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:5:1" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 5, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dominum esse ad villam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,015:chapter=20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sull. 20</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:chapter=21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 21</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">errantem ad flumina,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:6:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 6, 64</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:10:38" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 1, 10, 38</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:2:section=12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 2, § 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:7:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 7, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:7:12" default="NO" valid="yes">7, 12</bibl>; and ellipt. (cf. supra, 2. <foreign lang="greek">g</foreign>): <cit><quote lang="la">pecunia utinam ad Opis maneret!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:1:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 1, 17</bibl></cit>.—Even of persons: <cit><quote lang="la">qui primum pilum ad Caesarem duxerat (for apud),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:6:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 6, 38</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 31</bibl>; 3, 9; 5, 53; 7, 5; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. C. 3, 60</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad inferos poenas parricidii luent,</quote> <trans><tr>among</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:14:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 14, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque segnius ad hostes bellum apparatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:7:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 7, 7, 4</bibl></cit>: pugna ad Trebiam, ad Trasimenum, ad Cannas, etc., for which Liv. also uses the <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si Trasimeni quam Trebiae, si Cannarum quam Trasimeni pugna nobilior esset, 23, 43, 4.—Sometimes used to form the name of a place, although written separately, e. g. ad Murcim,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=154" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 154</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">villa ad Gallinas, a villa on the Flaminian Way,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 30, 40, § 37</bibl></cit>: ad urbem esse (of generals), <hi rend="ital">to remain outside the city</hi> (Rome) <hi rend="ital">until permission was given for a triumph</hi>: “Esse ad urbem dicebantur, qui cum potestate provinciali aut nuper e provincia revertissent, aut nondum in provinciam profecti essent ... solebant autem, qui ob res in provincia gestas triumphum peterent, extra urbem exspectare, donec, lege lata, triumphantes urbem introire possent,” Manut. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 3, 8</bibl>.—So sometimes with names of towns and verbs of rest: <cit><quote lang="la">pons, qui erat ad Genavam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad Tibur mortem patri minatus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:6:4:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 6, 4, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">conchas ad Caietam legunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:2:6" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 2, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad forum esse,</quote> <trans><tr>to be at the market</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:4:7:136" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 4, 7, 136</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:3:2:158" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 3, 2, 158</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Ter.</author> Ph. 4, 2, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:5:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> And. 1, 5, 19</bibl>.—Hence, adverb., ad dextram (sc. manum, partem), ad laevam, ad sinistram, <hi rend="ital">to the right</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to the left</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">on the right</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on the left</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad dextram,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0400,001:Rib. Trag. Rel. p. 225" default="NO"><author>Att.</author> Rib. Trag. Rel. p. 225</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:3:4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 3, 4, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:4:2:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 4, 2, 44</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,072:chapter=13" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Univ. 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 69</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad laevam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Enn.</author> Rib. Trag. Rel. p. 51</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0400,001:ib. p. 217" default="NO"><author>Att.</author> ib. p. 217</bibl>: ad sinistram, Ter. <pb n="28" /> <cb n="AD" /> Ad. 4, 2, 43 al.: <cit><quote lang="la">ad dextram ... ad laevam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 40, 6</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">and with an ordinal number: cum plebes ad tertium milliarium consedisset,</quote> <trans><tr>at the third milestone</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:14:54" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 14, 54</bibl></cit>, esp. freq. with <hi rend="ital">lapis</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">sepultus ad quintum lapidem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:22:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 22, 4</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:69 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 69 al.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 18</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 60</bibl> (with <hi rend="ital">apud</hi>, Ann. 1, 45; 3, 45; 15, 60) al.; cf. Rudd. II. p. 287.</sense><sense id="n665.14" n="B" level="2"> In time, analogous to the relations given in A. </sense><sense id="n665.15" n="1" level="3"> Direction toward, i. e. approach to a definite point of time, <hi rend="ital">about</hi>, <hi rend="ital">toward</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">domum reductus ad vesperum,</quote> <trans><tr>toward evening</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:3:12" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 3, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum ad hiemem me ex Cilicia recepissem,</quote> <trans><tr>toward winter</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 3, 7</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n665.16" n="2" level="3"> The limit or boundary to which a space of time extends, with and without <hi rend="ital">usque</hi>, <hi rend="ital">till</hi>, <hi rend="ital">until</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">even to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">up to</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ego ad illud frugi usque et probus fui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:1:2:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 1, 2, 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">philosophia jacuit usque ad hanc aetatem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:3:5" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 3, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> de Sen. 14</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid si hic manebo potius ad meridiem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:3:1:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 3, 1, 55</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:5:7:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. 5, 7, 33</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:5:116" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 1, 5, 116</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:2:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> As. 2, 1, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad multam noctem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> de Sen. 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Sophocles ad summam senectutem tragoedias fecit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 1, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Alexandream se proficisci velle dixit (Aratus) remque integram ad reditum suum jussit esse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:23:82" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 2, 23, 82</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bestiae ex se natos amant ad quoddam tempus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:chapter=8" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lael. 8</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> de Sen. 6</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Somn. Sc. 1 al.</bibl> —And with <hi rend="ital">ab</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ab-usque</hi>, to desig. the whole period of time passed away: <cit><quote lang="la">ab hora octava ad vesperum secreto collocuti sumus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">usque ab aurora ad hoc diei,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:1:2:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 1, 2, 8</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n665.17" n="3" level="3"> Coincidence with a point of time, <hi rend="ital">at</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in</hi>, <hi rend="ital">by</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">praesto fuit ad horam destinatam,</quote> <trans><tr>at the appointed hour</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:22" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admonuit ut pecuniam ad diem solverent,</quote> <trans><tr>on the day of payment</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:16:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 16, 16</bibl></cit> A: <cit><quote lang="la">nostra ad diem dictam fient,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:16:10:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 16, 10, 4</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 5</bibl>: ad lucem denique arte et graviter dormitare coepisse, <hi rend="ital">at</hi> (not toward) <hi rend="ital">daybreak</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:28:59" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 1, 28, 59</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 1, 3, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 4, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:31:103" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 2, 31, 103</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:97:313" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 97, 313</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad id tempus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 24</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 70:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 70, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 60</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:87" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 87</bibl>; Domit. 17, 21 al.</sense><sense id="n665.18" n="C" level="2"> The relations of number. </sense><sense id="n665.19" n="1" level="3"> An approximation <hi rend="ital">to</hi> a sum designated, <hi rend="ital">near</hi>, <hi rend="ital">near to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">almost</hi>, <hi rend="ital">about</hi>, <hi rend="ital">toward</hi> (cf. Gr. <foreign lang="greek">e)pi/, pro/s</foreign> with <case>acc.</case> and the Fr. <hi rend="ital">près de</hi>, <hi rend="ital">à peu près</hi>, <hi rend="ital">presque</hi>) = <hi rend="ital">circiter</hi> (Hand, Turs. I. p. 102): <cit><quote lang="la">ad quadraginta eam posse emi minas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:2:2:111" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 2, 2, 111</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nummorum Philippūm ad tria milia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1:2:115" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 1, 2, 115</bibl></cit>; sometimes with <hi rend="ital">quasi</hi> added: <cit><quote lang="la">quasi ad quadraginta minas,</quote> <trans><tr>as it were about</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:3:1:95" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 3, 1, 95</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:1:1:93" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 1, 1, 93</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sane frequentes fuimus omnino ad ducentos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 2, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum annos ad quadraginta natus esset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:40:110" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 40, 110</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad hominum milia decem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oppida numero ad duodecim, vicos ad quadringentos,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 5</bibl></cit>.—In the histt. and post-Aug. authors <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> is added adverbially in this sense (contrary to Gr. usage, by which <foreign lang="greek">a)mfi/, peri/</foreign>, and <foreign lang="greek">ei)s</foreign> with numerals retain their power as prepositions): ad binum milium numero utrinque sauciis factis, Sisenn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 80, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">occisis ad hominum milibus quattuor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad duorum milium numero ceciderunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. C. 3, 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad duo milia et trecenti occisi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:17:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 10, 17, 8</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:12:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 27, 12, 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:20" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 20</bibl>; cf. Rudd. II. p. 334.—</sense><sense id="n665.20" n="2" level="3"> The <hi rend="ital">terminus</hi>, the limit, <hi rend="ital">to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unto</hi>, <hi rend="ital">even to</hi>, a designated number (rare): <cit><quote lang="la">ranam luridam conicere in aquam usque quo ad tertiam partem decoxeris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:2:26" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 2, 26</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 41</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aedem Junonis ad partem dimidiam detegit,</quote> <trans><tr>even to the half</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 42, 3, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">miles (viaticum) ad assem perdiderat,</quote> <trans><tr>to a farthing</tr>, <tr>to the last farthing</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 2, 27</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:1:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 1, 15</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid ad denarium solveretur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Quint. 4</bibl></cit>.—The phrase omnes ad unum or ad unum omnes, or simply ad unum, means lit. <hi rend="ital">all to one</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">all together</hi>, <hi rend="ital">all without exception;</hi> Gr. <foreign lang="greek">oi( kaq) e(/na pa/ntes</foreign> (therefore the gender of unum is changed according to that of omnes): praetor omnes extra castra, ut stercus, foras ejecit ad unum, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 394, 22</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">de amicitia omnes ad unum idem sentiunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:chapter=23" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad unum omnes cum ipso duce occisi sunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:1:22 al" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 1, 22 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">naves Rhodias afflixit ita, ut ad unam omnes constratae eliderentur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 27</bibl></cit>; onerariae<cb n="AD" />  omnes ad unam a nobis sunt exceptae, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:12:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 12, 14</bibl> (cf. in Gr. <foreign lang="greek">oi( kaq) e(/na</foreign>; in Hebr. <foreign />, Exod. 14, 28).—<hi rend="ital">Ad unum</hi> without <hi rend="ital">omnes</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ego eam sententiam dixi, cui sunt assensi ad unum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:10:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 10, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Juppiter omnipotens si nondum exosus ad unum Trojanos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:687" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 687</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n665.21" n="D" level="2"> In the manifold relations of one object to another. </sense><sense id="n665.22" n="1" level="3"> That in respect of or in regard to which a thing avails, happens, or is true or important, <hi rend="ital">with regard to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in respect of</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in relation to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in.</hi> </sense><sense id="n665.23" n="a" level="4"> With <hi rend="ital">verbs</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad omnia alia aetate sapimus rectius,</quote> <trans><tr>in respect to all other things we grow wiser by age</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:5:3:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 5, 3, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">numquam ita quisquam bene ad vitam fuat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 4, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nil ibi libatum de toto corpore (mortui) cernas ad speciem, nil ad pondus,</quote> <trans><tr>that nothing is lost in form or weight</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:214" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 214</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:570" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 570</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:21:section=58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 21, § 58</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:13:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mur. 13, 29</bibl>: illi regi Cyro subest, ad immutandi animi licentiam, crudelissimus ille Phalaris, <hi rend="ital">in that Cyrus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in regard to the liberty of changing his disposition</hi> (i. e. not in reality, but inasmuch as he is at liberty to lay aside his good character, and assume that of a tyrant), <hi rend="ital">there is concealed another cruel Phalaris</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:28" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 1, 28</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nil est ad nos,</quote> <trans><tr>is nothing to us</tr>, <tr>concerns us not</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:830" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 830</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:845" default="NO" valid="yes">3, 845</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nil ad me attinet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:1:2:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 1, 2, 54</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil ad rem pertinet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:chapter=58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Caecin. 58</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">and in the same sense elliptically: nihil ad Epicurum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:2:5" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 1, 2, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:chapter=68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 68</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quid ad praetorem?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:chapter=116" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 1, 116</bibl></cit> (this usage is not to be confounded with that under 4.).—</sense><sense id="n665.24" n="b" level="4"> With <hi rend="ital">adjectives</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad has res perspicax,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:2:3:129" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 2, 3, 129</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">virum ad cetera egregium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:7:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 37, 7, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">auxiliaribus ad pugnam non multum Crassus confidebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ejus frater aliquantum ad rem est avidior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:1:2:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 1, 2, 51</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:2:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> And. 1, 2, 21</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:2:3:129" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 2, 3, 129</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut sit potior, qui prior ad dandum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:3:2:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phorm. 3, 2, 48</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">difficilis (res) ad credendum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:1027" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 1027</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad rationem sollertiamque praestantior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:62" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 62</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:13:33" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 2, 13, 33</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:20:63" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 2, 20, 63</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:30:85" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 30, 85</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,007:chapter=15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Font. 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:5:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 1, 5, 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:25:113" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 25, 113</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 32, 146</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 49, 200</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 3, 1, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:16:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 9, 16, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:12:54 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 12, 54 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n665.25" n="c" level="4"> With <hi rend="ital">nouns</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">prius quam tuum, ut sese habeat, animum ad nuptias perspexerit,</quote> <trans><tr>before he knew your feeling in regard to the marriage</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:2:3:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 2, 3, 4</bibl></cit> (cf. Gr. <foreign lang="greek">o(/pws e)/xei tis pro/s ti</foreign>): <cit><quote lang="la">mentis ad omnia caecitas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:5:11" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 5, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">magna vis est fortunae in utramque partem vel ad secundas res vel ad adversas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:6" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 2, 6</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,047:chapter=1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Par. 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad cetera paene gemelli,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 10, 3</bibl></cit>.—So with <case>acc.</case> of gerund instead of the <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> from the same vb.: <cit><quote lang="la">facultas ad scribendum, instead of scribendi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,007:chapter=6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Font. 6</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">facultas ad agendum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> de Imp. Pomp. 1, 2</bibl></cit>: cf. Rudd. II. p. 245.—</sense><sense id="n665.26" n="d" level="4"> In gramm.: nomina ad aliquid dicta, <hi rend="ital">nouns used in relation to something</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">which derive their significance from their relation to another object</hi>: quae non possunt intellegi sola, ut pater, mater; <cit><quote lang="la">jungunt enim sibi et illa propter quae intelleguntur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> 129</bibl></cit> P.; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 580</bibl> ib.—</sense><sense id="n665.27" n="2" level="3"> With words denoting measure, weight, manner, model, rule, etc., both prop. and fig., <hi rend="ital">according to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">agreeably to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">after</hi> (Gr. <foreign lang="greek">kata/, pro/s</foreign>): <cit><quote lang="la">columnas ad perpendiculum exigere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:chapter=77" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mur. 77</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">taleis ferreis ad certum pondus examinatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 12</bibl></cit>: facta sunt ad certam formam. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:379" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 379</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad amussim non est numerus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:2:1:26" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> 2, 1, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad imaginem facere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:1:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 1, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad cursus lunae describit annum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnia ad diem facta sunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Id ad similitudinem panis efficiebant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. C. 3, 48</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:1:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 1, 26</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,020:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Jac. 3, 9</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad aequos flexus,</quote> <trans><tr>at equal angles</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:323" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 323</bibl></cit>: quasi ad tornum levantur, <hi rend="ital">to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">by the lathe</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:361" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 4, 361</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">turres ad altitudiem valli,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 42</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 39, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad eandem crassitudinem structi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:44:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 44, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad speciem cancellorum scenicorum,</quote> <trans><tr>with the appearance of</tr>, <tr>like</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:5:8" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 5, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">stagnum maris instar, circumseptum aedificiis ad urbium speciem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:31" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lascivum pecus ludens ad cantum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0094,001:Rib. Trag. Rel. p. 1" default="NO"><author>Liv. Andron.</author> Rib. Trag. Rel. p. 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">canere ad tibiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:2" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 2</bibl></cit>: canere ad tibicinem,<cb n="AD" />  <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 2</bibl> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">in numerum ludere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:6:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 6, 28</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:175" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 4, 175</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">quod ad Aristophanis lucernam lucubravi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=9" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 9</bibl></cit> Müll.: carmen castigare ad unguem, <hi rend="ital">to perfection</hi> (v. unguis), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:294" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 294</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad unguem factus homo,</quote> <trans><tr>a perfect gentleman</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:5:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> S. 1, 5, 32</bibl></cit> (cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 7, 86</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">ad istorum normam sapientes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:5:18" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 5, 18</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:chapter=3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mur. 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Cyrus non ad historiae fidem scriptus, sed ad effigiem justi imperii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:1:1:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Q. Fr. 1, 1, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">exercemur in venando ad similitudinem bellicae disciplinae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:64:161" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 64, 161</bibl></cit>: so, <cit><quote lang="la">ad simulacrum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 40, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad Punica ingenia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 21, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad L. Crassi eloquentiam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Var. Fragm. 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnia fient ad verum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:6:324" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 6, 324</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid aut ad naturam aut contra sit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:9:30" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 1, 9, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad hunc modum institutus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 2, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 31</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 13</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad eundem istunc modum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:3:3:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 3, 3, 70</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quem ad modum, q. v.: ad istam faciem est morbus, qui me macerat,</quote> <trans><tr>of that kind</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,007:1:1:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cist. 1, 1, 73</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:2:3:90" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Merc. 2, 3, 90</bibl>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">91: cujus ad arbitrium copia materiai cogitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:281" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 281</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad eorum arbitrium et nutum totos se fingunt,</quote> <trans><tr>to their will and pleasure</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:8:24" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 8, 24</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Quint. 71</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad P. Lentuli auctoritatem Romā contendit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,030:chapter=21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rab. Post. 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliae sunt legati partes, aliae imperatoris: alter omnia agere ad praescriptum, alter libere ad summam rerum consulere debet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rebus ad voluntatem nostram fluentibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:26" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rem ad illorum libidinem judicārunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,007:chapter=36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Font. 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad vulgi opinionem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:21" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 21</bibl></cit>.—So in later Lat. with <hi rend="ital">instar</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad instar castrorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:36:3:2" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 36, 3, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">scoparum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 9, p. 232</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">speculi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2</bibl></cit>, p. 118: ad hoc instar mundi, id. de Mundo, p. 72.—Sometimes, but very rarely, ad is used <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> in this sense (so also very rarely <foreign lang="greek">kata/</foreign> with <case>acc.</case>, Xen. Hell. 2, 3; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:Dial. Deor. 8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> Dial. Deor. 8</bibl>): convertier ad nos, <hi rend="ital">as we</hi> (are turned), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:317" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 317</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad navīs feratur,</quote> <trans><tr>like ships</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:897" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 4, 897</bibl></cit> Munro. —With <hi rend="ital">noun</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad specus angustiac vallium,</quote> <trans><tr>like caves</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 49</bibl></cit>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n665.28" n="3" level="3"> With an object which is the cause or reason, in conformity to which, from which, or for which, any thing is or is done. </sense><sense id="n665.29" n="a" level="4"> The moving cause, <hi rend="ital">according to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">at</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in consequence of</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cetera pars animae paret et ad numen mentis momenque movetur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:144" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 144</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad horum preces in Boeotiam duxit,</quote> <trans><tr>on their entreaty</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:67:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 42, 67, 12</bibl></cit>: ad ea Caesar veniam ipsique et conjugi et fratribus tribuit, <hi rend="ital">in consequence of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">upon this</hi>, <hi rend="ital">he</hi>, etc., <bibl default="NO"><author>Tac.</author> Ann. 12, 37</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n665.30" n="b" level="4"> The final cause, or the object, end, or aim, for the attainment of which any thing, </sense><sense id="n665.31" n="(a)" level="5"> is done, </sense><sense id="n665.32" n="(b)" level="5"> is designed, or, </sense><sense id="n665.33" n="(g)" level="5"> is fitted or adapted (very freq.), <hi rend="ital">to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">for</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in order to.</hi> </sense><sense id="n665.34" n="(a)" level="5"> Seque ad ludos jam inde abhinc exerceant, Pac. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 175</bibl> P. (R<bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Trag. Rel. p. 80</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">venimus coctum ad nuptias,</quote> <trans><tr>in order to cook for the wedding</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:3:2:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 3, 2, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnis ad perniciem instructa domus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:3:1:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 3, 1, 6</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:3:1:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 3, 1, 41</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 54</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum fingis falsas causas ad discordiam,</quote> <trans><tr>in order to produce dissension</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:4:4:71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 4, 4, 71</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quantam fenestram ad nequitiam patefeceris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:3:1:72" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 3, 1, 72</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">utrum ille, qui postulat legatum ad tantum bellum, quem velit, idoneus non est, qui impetret, cum ceteri ad expilandos socios diripiendasque provincias, quos voluerunt, legatos eduxerint,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> de Imp. Pomp. 19, 57</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ego vitam quoad putabo tua interesse, aut ad spem servandam esse, retinebo,</quote> <trans><tr>for hope</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Q. Fr. 1, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 5, 17</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec juventutem, ubi familiares opes defecerant, ad facinora incendebant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 13:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 13, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad speciem atque ad usurpationem vetustatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:12:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Agr. 2, 12, 31</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:67" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 67</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">paucis ad speciem tabernaculis relictis,</quote> <trans><tr>for appearance</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 35</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 41</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. G. 1, 51</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n665.35" n="(b)" level="5"> Aut equos alere aut canes ad venandum. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:1:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 1, 30</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ingenio egregie ad miseriam natus sum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:3:1:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 3, 1, 11</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">(in the same sense: in rem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:27:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 27, 1</bibl></cit>, and the <case>dat.</case>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:4:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 4, 2, 6</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">ad cursum equum, ad arandum bovem, ad indagandum canem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:13:40" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 13, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad frena leones,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:253" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 253</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">delecto ad naves milite,</quote> <trans><tr>marines</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 22, 19</bibl></cit> Weissenb.: <cit><quote lang="la">servos ad remum,</quote> <trans><tr>rowers</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 34, 6</bibl></cit>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">servos ad militiam emendos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:61:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 22, 61, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">comparāsti ad lecticam homines,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:10:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 10, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Lygdamus ad cyathos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4:8:37" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4, 8, 37</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">puer ad cyathum statuetur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:29:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 29, 8</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n665.36" n="(g)" level="5"> Quae oportet Signa esse <pb n="29" /> <cb n="AD" /> ad salutem, omnia huic osse video, <hi rend="ital">everything indicative of prosperity I see in him</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:3:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 3, 2, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec sunt ad virtutem omnia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:1:2:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 1, 2, 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">causa ad objurgandum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:1:123" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> And. 1, 1, 123</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">argumentum ad scribendum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:9:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 9, 7</bibl></cit> (in both examples instead of the <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> of <hi rend="ital">gerund.</hi>, cf. Rudd. II. p. 245): <cit><quote lang="la">vinum murteum est ad alvum crudam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0022,001:125" default="NO"><author>Cato</author> R. R. 125</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nulla res tantum ad dicendum proficit, quantum scriptio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=24" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">reliquis rebus, quae sunt ad incendia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:101 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 101 al.</bibl></cit>—So with the adjectives <hi rend="ital">idoneus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">utilis</hi>, <hi rend="ital">aptus</hi>, instead of the <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">homines ad hanc rem idoneos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:3:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 3, 2, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">calcei habiles et apti ad pedem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:54:231" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 54, 231</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">orator aptus tamen ad dicendum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:3:5" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 3, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sus est ad vescendum hominibus apta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:64:160" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 64, 160</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">homo ad nullam rem utilis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:6" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad segetes ingeniosus ager,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:4:684" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 4, 684</bibl></cit>.—(Upon the connection of <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> with the <hi rend="ital">gerund.</hi> v. Zumpt, § 666; Rudd.
