II. p. 261.)—</sense><sense id="n665.37" n="4" level="3"> Comparison (since that with which a thing is compared is considered as an object to which the thing compared is brought near for the sake of comparison), <hi rend="ital">to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">compared to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">with</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in comparison with</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad sapientiam hujus ille (Thales) nimius nugator fuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:2:2:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 2, 2, 25</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:3:2:100" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 3, 2, 100</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne comparandus hic quidem ad illum'st,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:4:4:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 4, 4, 14</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 3, 69</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">terra ad universi caeli complexum,</quote> <trans><tr>compared with the whole extent of the heavens</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:17:40" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 17, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">homini non ad cetera Punica ingenia callido,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:22:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 22, 22, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">at nihil ad nostram hanc,</quote> <trans><tr>nothing in comparison with</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:2:3:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 2, 3, 70</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:8:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Deiot. 8, 24</bibl>; and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:6:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 6, 25</bibl>.</sense><sense id="n665.38" n="E" level="2"> Adverbial phrases with <hi rend="ital">ad.</hi> </sense><sense id="n665.39" n="1" level="3"> Ad omnia, <hi rend="ital">withal</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to crown all</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ingentem vim peditum equitumque venire: ex India elephantos: ad omnia tantum advehi auri, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:35:32:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 35, 32, 4</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n665.40" n="2" level="3"> Ad hoc and ad haec (in the historians, esp. from the time of Livy, and in authors after the Aug. per.), = praeterea, insuper, <hi rend="ital">moreover</hi>, <hi rend="ital">besides</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in addition</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">e)pi/ tou/tois</foreign>: <cit><quote lang="la">nam quicumque impudicus, adulter, ganeo, etc.: praeterea omnes undique parricidae, etc.: ad hoc, quos manus atque lingua perjurio aut sanguine civili alebat: postremo omnes, quos, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 14:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 14, 2</bibl></cit> and 3: <cit><quote lang="la">his opinionibus inflato animo, ad hoc vitio quoque ingenii vehemens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:11:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 6, 11, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes">42, 1, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:22 al" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 22 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n665.41" n="3" level="3"> Ad id quod, <hi rend="ital">beside that</hi> (very rare): <cit><quote lang="la">ad id quod sua sponte satis conlectum animorum erat, indignitate etiam Romani accendebantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:62:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 62, 1</bibl></cit>; so 44, 37, 12.—</sense><sense id="n665.42" n="4" level="3"> Ad tempus. </sense><sense id="n665.43" n="a" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">At a definite</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fixed time</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 13, 45</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:25:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 25, 3</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n665.44" n="b" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">At a fit</hi>, <hi rend="ital">appropriate time</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:54:section=141" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 54, § 141</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:7:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 7, 13</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n665.45" n="c" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">For some time</hi>, <hi rend="ital">for a short time</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:8:27" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 8, 27</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:15:53" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lael. 15, 53</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:25:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 25, 14</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n665.46" n="d" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">According to circumstances</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:30:74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Planc. 30, 74</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:6:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cael. 6, 13</bibl>; Planc. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:10:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 10, 9</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n665.47" n="5" level="3"> Ad praesens (for the most part only in post-Aug. writers). </sense><sense id="n665.48" n="a" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">For the moment</hi>, <hi rend="ital">for a short time</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:12:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 12, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:22:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 22, 34</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 21</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n665.49" n="b" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">At present</hi>, <hi rend="ital">now</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:16:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 16, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 1, 44</bibl>.—So, ad praesentiam, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:11:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 11, 8</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n665.50" n="6" level="3"> Ad locum, <hi rend="ital">on the spot</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut ad locum miles esset paratus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:27:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 27, 27, 2</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n665.51" n="7" level="3"> Ad verbum, <hi rend="ital">word for word</hi>, <hi rend="ital">literally</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:2:4" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 1, 2, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:34:157" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 34, 157</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 44, 135 al.</bibl>— </sense><sense id="n665.52" n="8" level="3"> Ad summam. </sense><sense id="n665.53" n="a" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">On the whole</hi>, <hi rend="ital">generally</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in general</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:14:14:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 14, 14, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:14:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 14, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:71" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 71</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n665.54" n="b" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">In a word</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in short</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:41:149" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 41, 149</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 1, 106</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n665.55" n="9" level="3"> Ad extremum, ad ultimum, ad postremum. </sense><sense id="n665.56" n="a" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">At the end</hi>, <hi rend="ital">finally</hi>, <hi rend="ital">at last.</hi> </sense><sense id="n665.57" n="(a)" level="5"> Of place, <hi rend="ital">at the extremity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">extreme point</hi>, <hi rend="ital">top</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">missile telum hastili abiegno et cetera tereti, praeterquam ad extremum, unde ferrum exstabat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:8:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 8, 10</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n665.58" n="(b)" level="5"> Of time = <foreign lang="greek">te/los de/</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">at last</hi>, <hi rend="ital">finally</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ibi ad postremum cedit miles,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:3:5:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 3, 5, 52</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:4:2:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Poen. 4, 2, 22</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:23:89" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 23, 89</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:13:20:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 13, 20, 45</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 53</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:15:4 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 30, 15, 4 al.</bibl>— Hence, </sense><sense id="n665.59" n="(g)" level="5"> of order, <hi rend="ital">finally</hi>, <hi rend="ital">lastly</hi>, = denique: inventa componere; tum ornare oratione; post memoria sepire; <cit><quote lang="la">ad extremum agere cum dignitate,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:31:142" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 31, 142</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n665.60" n="b" level="4"> In Liv., <hi rend="ital">to the last degree</hi>, <hi rend="ital">quite</hi>: improbus homo, sed non ad extremum perditus, 23, 2, 3; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">consilii scelerati, sed non ad ultimum dementis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> 28, 28, 8</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n665.61" n="10" level="3"> Quem ad finem? <hi rend="ital">To what limit? How far?</hi> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 1, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:75" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 5, 75</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n665.62" n="11" level="3"> Quem ad modum, v. sub h. v. <cb n="ADAE" />!*? </sense><sense id="n665.63" n="a" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Ad</hi> (v. ab, ex, in, etc.) is not repeated like some other prepositions with interrog. and relative pronouns, after nouns or demonstrative pronouns: <cit><quote lang="la">traducis cogitationes meas ad voluptates. Quas? corporis credo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:17:37" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 17, 37</bibl></cit> (ubi v. Kühner).—</sense><sense id="n665.64" n="b" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Ad</hi> is sometimes placed after its substantive: <cit><quote lang="la">quam ad,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:3:2:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 3, 2, 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">senatus, quos ad soleret, referendum censuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:4" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ripam ad Araxis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tac.</author> Ann. 12, 51</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">or between subst. and adj.: augendam ad invidiam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 12, 8</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n665.65" n="c" level="4"> The compound adque for et ad (like exque, eque, and, <usg type="style">poet.</usg>, aque) is denied by Moser, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:15, p. 248" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 2, 15, p. 248</bibl>, and he reads instead of ad humanitatem <hi rend="ital">adque</hi> mansuetudinem of the MSS., hum. <hi rend="ital">atque</hi> mans. But adque, in acc. with later usage, is restored by Hand in <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 10, p. 247</bibl>, adque haec omnia oboediebam for <hi rend="ital">atque;</hi> and in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:2:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 2, 3, 9</bibl>, utroque vorsum rectum'st ingenium meum, ad se adque illum, is now read, ad te atque ad illum (Fleck., Brix).</sense><sense id="n665.66" n="II" level="1"> In composition. </sense><sense id="n665.67" n="A" level="2"> Form. According to the usual orthography, the <hi rend="ital">d</hi> of the ad remains unchanged before vowels, and before <hi rend="ital">b</hi>, <hi rend="ital">d</hi>, <hi rend="ital">h</hi>, <hi rend="ital">m</hi>, <hi rend="ital">v</hi>: adbibo, adduco, adhibeo, admoveo, advenio; it is assimilated to <hi rend="ital">c</hi>, <hi rend="ital">f</hi>, <hi rend="ital">g</hi>, <hi rend="ital">l</hi>, <hi rend="ital">n</hi>, <hi rend="ital">p</hi>, <hi rend="ital">r</hi>, <hi rend="ital">s</hi>, <hi rend="ital">t</hi>: accipio, affigo, aggero, allabor, annumero, appello, arripio, assumo, attineo; before <hi rend="ital">g</hi> and <hi rend="ital">s</hi> it sometimes disappears: agnosco, aspicio, asto: and before <hi rend="ital">qu</hi> it passes into <hi rend="ital">c</hi>: acquiro, acquiesco.—But later philologists, supported by old inscriptions and good MSS., have mostly adopted the following forms: <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> before <hi rend="ital">j</hi>, <hi rend="ital">h</hi>, <hi rend="ital">b</hi>, <hi rend="ital">d</hi>, <hi rend="ital">f</hi>, <hi rend="ital">m</hi>, <hi rend="ital">n</hi>, <hi rend="ital">q</hi>, <hi rend="ital">v; ac</hi> before <hi rend="ital">c</hi>, sometimes, but less well, before <hi rend="ital">q; ag</hi> and also <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> before <hi rend="ital">g; a</hi> before <hi rend="ital">gn</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sp</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sc</hi>, <hi rend="ital">st; ad</hi> and also <hi rend="ital">al</hi> before <hi rend="ital">l; ad</hi> rather than <hi rend="ital">an</hi> before <hi rend="ital">n; ap</hi> and sometimes <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> before <hi rend="ital">p; ad</hi> and also <hi rend="ital">ar</hi> before <hi rend="ital">r; ad</hi> and also <hi rend="ital">as</hi> before <hi rend="ital">s; at</hi> and sometimes <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> before <hi rend="ital">t.</hi> In this work the old orthography has commonly been retained for the sake of convenient reference, but the better form in any case is indicated.—</sense><sense id="n665.68" n="B" level="2"> Signif. In English <hi rend="ital">up</hi> often denotes <hi rend="ital">approach</hi>, and in many instances will give the force of <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> as a prefix both in its local and in its figurative sense. </sense><sense id="n665.69" n="1" level="3"> Local. </sense><sense id="n665.70" n="a" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">To</hi>, <hi rend="ital">toward</hi>: affero, accurro, accipio (<hi rend="ital">to</hi> one's self).—</sense><sense id="n665.71" n="b" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">At</hi>, <hi rend="ital">by</hi>: astare, adesse.—</sense><sense id="n665.72" n="c" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">On</hi>, <hi rend="ital">upon</hi>, <hi rend="ital">against</hi>: accumbo, attero.—</sense><sense id="n665.73" n="d" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Up</hi> (cf. de- = <hi rend="ital">down</hi>, as in deicio, decĭdo): attollo, ascendo, adsurgo.—</sense><sense id="n665.74" n="2" level="3"> Fig. </sense><sense id="n665.75" n="a" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">To</hi>: adjudico, adsentior.—</sense><sense id="n665.76" n="b" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">At</hi> or <hi rend="ital">on</hi>: admiror, adludo.—</sense><sense id="n665.77" n="c" level="4"> Denoting <hi rend="ital">conformity to</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">comparison with</hi>: affiguro, adaequo.—</sense><sense id="n665.78" n="d" level="4"> Denoting <hi rend="ital">addition</hi>, <hi rend="ital">increase</hi> (cf. <hi rend="ital">ab</hi>, <hi rend="ital">de</hi>, and <hi rend="ital">ex</hi> as prefixes to denote <hi rend="ital">privation</hi>): addoceo, adposco.—</sense><sense id="n665.79" n="e" level="4"> Hence, denoting <hi rend="ital">intensity</hi>: adamo, adimpleo, aduro, and perhaps agnosco.—</sense><sense id="n665.80" n="f" level="4"> Denoting the coming to an act or state, and hence <hi rend="ital">commencement</hi>: addubito, addormio, adquiesco, adlubesco, advesperascit. See more upon this word in Hand, Turs. I. pp. 74-134.</sense></entryFree>
adactio: <entryFree id="n666" type="main" key="a^dacti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădactĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>adigo</etym>, <sense id="n666.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a forcing</hi> or <hi rend="ital">bringing to</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad legitimam juris jurandi adactionem,</quote> <trans><tr>to the taking of an oath</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 22, 38</bibl></cit>, where just before we find: milites jurejurando adacti.</sense></entryFree>
adactus: <entryFree id="n667" type="main" key="a^dactus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădactus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of adigo.</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n668" type="hapax" key="a^dactus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădactus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>adigo</etym>, <sense id="n668.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a forcing</hi> or <hi rend="ital">bringing to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">together.</hi>—Hence, <usg type="style">poet.</usg>, of the teeth, <hi rend="ital">a biting</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a bite</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">dentis adactus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1330" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 1330</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adad: <entryFree id="n669" type="main" key="Adad"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Adad</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Adădus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n669.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">name of the supreme god of the Assyrians</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> Sat. 1, 32</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adadunephros: <entryFree id="n670" type="greek" key="adadu_ne^phros"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adadūnĕphros</orth> = <foreign lang="greek">*)ada/dou vefro/s</foreign> (Adad's kidney), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>Adad</etym>, <sense id="n670.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a certain precious stone</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:186" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 11, 71, § 186</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adaequatio: <entryFree id="n671" type="main" key="a^daequa_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădaequātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>adaequo</etym>, <sense id="n671.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a making equal</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an adjusting</hi>, <hi rend="ital">adapting</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> ad Nat. 1, 1</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Sol.</author> 1</bibl>, where more correctly <hi rend="ital">peraequatio.</hi></sense></entryFree>
adaeque: <entryFree id="n672" type="main" key="a^daeque"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-aeque</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, <sense id="n672.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">in like manner as</hi>, <hi rend="ital">equally</hi>, <hi rend="ital">so</hi> (most. ante- and post-class.; not in Cic.; and in Plautus always with the negatives nemo, numquam, neque, nullus, etc., by means of which the clause acquires a compar. signif.; <cit><quote lang="la">hence, sometimes a compar. abl., and even a pleonastic compar., is allowed): numquam, ecastor, ullo die risi adaeque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:5:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 5, 1, 3</bibl></cit>: neque munda adaeque<cb n="ADAL" />  es, ut soles, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,007:1:1:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cist. 1, 1, 57</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:3:5:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cas. 3, 5, 45</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:5:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. 5, 4, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:Gl. 3:1:180" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. Gl. 3, 1, 180</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quo nemo adaeque antehac est habitus parcus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:1:1:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 1, 1, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quī homine hominum adaeque nemo vivit fortunatior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:4:2:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. 4, 2, 48</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut quem ad modum in tribunis consulari potestate creandis usi sunt, adaeque in quaestoribus liberum esset arbitrium populi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:43:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 43, 5</bibl></cit> Weissenb., Hertz. (but Madv. here reads <hi rend="ital">adaequari</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">alii, quos adaeque latrones arbitrabere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> 4, p. 145 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 8</bibl>, p. 216; 10, p. 238; Cod. Th. 8, 18, 4.</sense></entryFree>
adaequo: <entryFree id="n673" type="main" key="a^daequo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-aequo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> and <gen>n.</gen> <sense id="n673.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Act.</hi> </sense><sense id="n673.1" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To make equal to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to equalize</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to level with;</hi> hence, </sense><sense id="n673.2" n="a" level="4"> In Cic. usually with <hi rend="ital">cum</hi> (cf. aequare cum, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:193" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 193</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">qui cum virtute fortunam adaequavit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,016:10:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Arch. 10, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae ... admonet, commemorationem nominis nostri, cum omni posteritate adaequandam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 11, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in summa amicorum copia cum familiarissimis ejus est adaequatus (i. e. par habitus),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,026:28:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Balb. 28, 63</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n673.3" n="b" level="4"> In the histt. <hi rend="ital">alicui rei</hi> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">aequo and aequiparo): molibus ferme (oppidi) moenibus adaequatis,</quote> <trans><tr>on a level with</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnia tecta solo adaequare,</quote> <trans><tr>to level with the ground</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quibus duobus operibus vix nova haec magnificentia quidquam adaequare potuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:ib. 56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 56</bibl></cit>; and with <hi rend="ital">solo</hi> understood: <cit><quote lang="la">Alesiam flammis adaequare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:3:10:23" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 3, 10, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum Claudius libertos sibique et legibus adaequaverit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:12:60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 12, 60</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">colonias jure et dignatione urbi ... adaequavit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:46" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 46</bibl></cit>; so Dom. 2.—</sense><sense id="n673.4" n="2" level="3"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to compare to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">with</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui formam, aetatem, genus mortis magni Alexandri fatis adaequarent,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tac.</author> Ann. 2, 73</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n673.5" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To attain to</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">reach</hi>, <hi rend="ital">by equalling.</hi> —With <case>acc.</case> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">aequo and aequiparo): ne quid absit quod deorum vitam possit adaequare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,072:chapter=11" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Univ. 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">longarum navium cursum adaequaverunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut muri altitudinem acervi armorum adaequarent,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 32</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. C. 2, 16</bibl>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 4</bibl>.</sense><sense id="n673.6" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Neut.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be equal.</hi> </sense><sense id="n673.7" n="a" level="4"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: senatorum urna copiose absolvit, equitum adaequavit, <hi rend="ital">the votes of the</hi> equites <hi rend="ital">were equally divided</hi>, there was an equal number for acquitting and for condemning, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:2:6:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 2, 6, 6</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n673.8" n="b" level="4"> With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">turris quae moenibus adaequaret, Auct. B. G. 8, 41: se virtute nostris adaequare non posse intellegunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 16</bibl></cit> Dinter, where some read <hi rend="ital">nostros</hi>: adaequare apud Caesarem gratiā, sc. Aeduis, id. B: G. 6, 12.</sense></entryFree>
adaeratio: <entryFree id="n674" type="main" key="a^daera_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădaerātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>adaero</etym>, <sense id="n674.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a valuing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">appraising</hi>, Cod. Th. 11, 20, 6; 11, 38, 13; 7, 4, 32.</sense></entryFree>
adaero: <entryFree id="n675" type="main" key="a^daero"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-aero</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <sense id="n675.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. ā.</hi> [aes], <hi rend="ital">to estimate by money</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to rate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">appraise</hi>, <hi rend="ital">value</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in adaerandis reliquorum debitis non molestus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 31, 14</bibl></cit>: ita ut nihil adaeretur, i. e. ita ut nihil in pecunia praestetur, Ep. Imp. Valeriani ap. Trebell. <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> 14</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adaestuo: <entryFree id="n676" type="hapax" key="a^daestu^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-aestŭo</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <sense id="n676.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v.n.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to rush</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to roar</hi> (with the idea of <hi rend="ital">boiling up</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">adaestuat amnis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:5:517" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 5, 517</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adaggero: <entryFree id="n677" type="main" key="a^dagge^ro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-aggĕro</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> (a double ad, as in adalligo), <sense id="n677.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to heap up</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum ver adpetet, terram adaggerato bene,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 94</bibl></cit>: so, <cit><quote lang="la">terram circa arborem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:5:11:8" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 5, 11, 8</bibl></cit>: terra Nilo adaggerata, <hi rend="ital">brought down</hi> or <hi rend="ital">deposited by the Nile</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:13:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 13, 11, 21, § 69</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nitro et sale adaggeratis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:81" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 36, 12, 17, § 81</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adagio: <entryFree id="n678" type="main" key="a^da^gi^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădăgĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, a rare form for adagium: “<sense id="n678.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adagione</hi>: proverbio,” Gloss. Placid., Mai; Auct. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 7:section=31" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 7, § 31</bibl> Müll.; Aus. Monos. praef.</sense></entryFree>
adagium: <entryFree id="n679" type="main" key="a^da^gi^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădăgĭum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>prob. ad and aio, but acc. to Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=12" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 12</bibl> Müll., “ad agendum apta,” applicable to life, suitable for use</etym>, <sense id="n679.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a proverb</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an adage</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">vetus adagium est, Nihil cum fidibus graculo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:1" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 1</bibl></cit>, praef.</sense></entryFree>
adagnitio: <entryFree id="n680" type="main" key="a^dagni^ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-agnĭtĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>double ad, as in adaggero and adalligo</etym>, <sense id="n680.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">knowledge</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Dei ignoti adagnitionem intentare,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Marc. 4, 28</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adalgidus: <entryFree id="n681" type="main" key="adalgi^dus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-algĭdus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>ad, <hi rend="ital">intens.</hi></etym>, <sense id="n681.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">very cold</hi>, <hi rend="ital">chilly;</hi> of climate: <cit><quote lang="la">adalgidum maxime,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1248,001:, Ep. ad M. Caes. 2:9, p. 54" default="NO"><author>Fronto</author>, Ep. ad M. Caes. 2, 9, p. 54</bibl></cit> Mai; in Naev. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:45:152" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 45, 152</bibl>, Clussman would read <hi rend="ital">adalgidum</hi> for atque algidum (B. and K.).</sense></entryFree>
adalligo: <entryFree id="n682" type="main" key="a^dalli^go"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-allĭgo</orth>, <itype>āre, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> (double ad, as in adaggero), <sense id="n682.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to bind to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to fasten to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to attach</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">uncum (ad arborem),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:23:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 23, 35</bibl></cit>, <pb n="30" /> <cb n="ADAP" /> § <cit><quote lang="la">211: radices,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:225" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 20, 21, 84, § 225</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vermiculos bracchio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:89" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 27, 10, 62, § 89</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adam: <entryFree id="n683" type="main" key="A_^dam"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^dam</orth>, <itype>indecl.</itype> <gen>m.</gen>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> 94</bibl> P., or <sense id="n683.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> Adae, also <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^dāmus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <foreign />, <hi rend="ital">Adam</hi> (A common in quantity, cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> Apoth. 759</bibl> and 1078, with <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Idyll. 1, 14</bibl>).</sense></entryFree>
adamanteus: <entryFree id="n684" type="main" key="a^da^mante_us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădămantēus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>adamas</etym>, <sense id="n684.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of hard steel</hi>, <hi rend="ital">iron</hi>, etc., or <hi rend="ital">hard as these</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">catenae,</quote> <trans><tr>adamantine</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Manil.</author> 1, 921</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nares (taurorum),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:104" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 104</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adamantinus: <entryFree id="n685" type="greek" key="a^da^manti^nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădămantĭnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)dama/ntinos</foreign>, <sense id="n685.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">hard as steel</hi>, etc., <hi rend="ital">adamantine</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">saxa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:447" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 447</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">duritia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:11:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 11, 73</bibl></cit>. —Hence <usg type="style">poet.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">extremely hard</hi>, <hi rend="ital">inflexible</hi>, <hi rend="ital">invincible</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">clavi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:24:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 24, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tunica,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 6, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">juga,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:9:9" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3, 9, 9</bibl></cit>; cf. aënus.</sense></entryFree>
adamantis: <entryFree id="n686" type="main" key="a^da^mantis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădămantis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n686.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a certain magic herb</hi>, <hi rend="ital">which cannot be bruised</hi> or <hi rend="ital">crushed</hi> [<foreign lang="greek">a)-dama/w</foreign>], <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:24:162" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 24, 17, 102, § 162</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 4</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adamas: <entryFree id="n687" type="greek" key="a^da^mas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădămas</orth>, <itype>antis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (<case>acc.</case> Gr. adamanta, adamantas), = <foreign lang="greek">a)da/mas</foreign> (invincible), <sense id="n687.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adamant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the hard est iron</hi> or <hi rend="ital">steel;</hi> hence <usg type="style">poet.</usg>, for <hi rend="ital">any thing inflexible</hi>, <hi rend="ital">firm</hi>, <hi rend="ital">lasting</hi>, etc. (first used by Verg.): <cit><quote lang="la">porta adversa ingens solidoque adamante columnae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:552" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 552</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:5:11" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 5, 11</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">adamante texto vincire,</quote> <trans><tr>with adamantine chains</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Herc. F. 807" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Herc. F. 807</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Trop.</usg> of character, <hi rend="ital">hard</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unyielding</hi>, <hi rend="ital">inexorable</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec rigidos silices solidumve in pectore ferrum aut adamanta gerit,</quote> <trans><tr>a heart of stone</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:615" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 9, 615</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lacrimis adamanta movebis,</quote> <trans><tr>will move a heart of stone</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:1:659" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. A. 1, 659</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:4:8:45" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tr. 4, 8, 45</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">voce tua posses adamanta movere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:7:99" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 7, 99</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">duro nec enim ex adamante creati, Sed tua turba sumus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:1:2:69" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 1, 2, 69</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n687.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The diamond</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adamanta infragilem omni cetera vi sanguine hireino rumpente,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 20</bibl></cit>, prooem. 1; 37, 4, 15, § 55 sq.</sense></entryFree>
adamator: <entryFree id="n688" type="main" key="a^da^ma_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-ămātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n688.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a lover</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Hab. Mul. 2</bibl>.—In the Gloss. Graec. a transl. of <foreign lang="greek">e)rwtiko/s</foreign>.</sense></entryFree>
adambulo: <entryFree id="n689" type="main" key="a^dambu^lo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-ambŭlo</orth>, <itype>āre, 1</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, <sense id="n689.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to walk about</hi>, <hi rend="ital">at</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">near a thing</hi> (rare; <cit><quote lang="la">used only before and after the class. per.): ad ostium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:4:5:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 4, 5, 8</bibl></cit>.—Also with <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">seni,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 11, p. 261</bibl></cit>; so lateri, 3, 26.</sense></entryFree>
adamiani: <entryFree id="n690" type="main" key="A_^da_mi^a_ni"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^dāmĭāni</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n690.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">certain heretics who imitated the nakedness of Adam before the fall</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Or. 8, 5, 14</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adamo: <entryFree id="n691" type="main" key="a^da^mo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-ămo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>ad, <hi rend="ital">intens.</hi></etym>, <sense id="n691.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to love truly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">earnestly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">deeply</hi> (in the whole class. per. mostly—in Cic. always— used only in the <hi rend="ital">perf.</hi> and <hi rend="ital">pluperf.;</hi> first in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:10:199" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 10, 199</bibl>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:5:22" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 5, 22</bibl>, in the <hi rend="ital">pres.</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">nihil erat cujusquam, quod quidem ille adamāsset, quod non hoc anno suum fore putaret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:32:87" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mil. 32, 87</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 34</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 4, 45</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sententiam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 3, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Antisthenes patientiam et duritiam in Socratico sermone maxime adamārat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:17:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 3, 17, 62</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 19, 71</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">laudum gloriam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 2, 4 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Flacc. 11</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quem (Platonem) Dion admiratus est atque adamavit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Dion, 2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Dion, 2, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agros et cultus et copias Gallorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Achilleos equos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:3:4:28" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 3, 4, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">villas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:3:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 3, 7</bibl></cit>: si virtutem adamaveris, amare enim parum est (<hi rend="ital">amare</hi>, as the merely instinctive love of goodness, in contrast with the acquired love of the philosophers, Doederl.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 71:5" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 71, 5</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n691.1" n="II" level="1"> Of unlawful love, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:2:109" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 2, 109</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=vesp.:22" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Vesp. 22</bibl>: <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:155" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 42, 64, § 155</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 36, 5, 4, § 23</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0972,001:110 al" default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> S. 110 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
adampliatus: <entryFree id="n692" type="main" key="a^dampli^a_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădamplĭātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, from adamplio.</entryFree>
adamplio: <entryFree id="n693" type="main" key="a^dampli^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-amplĭo</orth>, <itype>āre, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>ad, den. <hi rend="ital">increase</hi></etym>, <sense id="n693.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to widen</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to enlarge</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to increase</hi>: adampliemus pondus, Vulg. Ital. Amos, 8, 5, where St. Jerome has <hi rend="ital">augeamus</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aediculam vetustate corruptam adampliavit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Grut.</author> 128, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">884, 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adamussim: <entryFree id="n694" type="main" key="a^da^mussim"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-ămussim</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. amussis.</entryFree>
adaperio: <entryFree id="n695" type="main" key="a^da^pe^ri^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-ăpĕrĭo</orth>, <itype>ui, ertum, 4</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>ad, <hi rend="ital">intens.</hi></etym>, <sense id="n695.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to open fully</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to open</hi>, <hi rend="ital">throw open</hi> (not in Cic.): <cit><quote lang="la">adorti adapertas fores portae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:30:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 25, 30, 10</bibl></cit> Drak. (cf. aperire forīs, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:2:1:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 2, 1, 13</bibl>); so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:12" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:9:7:24" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 9, 7, 24</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:1:5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 1, 5, 3</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 12, 12</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n695.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to uncover</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to bare</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">caput,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 64" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 64</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:5:2:9" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 5, 2, 9</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">caelum,</quote> <trans><tr>to make visible</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:130" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 47, 48, § 130</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adaperta fides,</quote> <trans><tr>manifest</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:1:396" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 1, 396</bibl></cit>: aures ad criminationem<cb n="ADDA" />  adapertae, <hi rend="ital">open to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ready to hear</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:9:7:24" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 9, 7, 24</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adapertilis: <entryFree id="n696" type="hapax" key="a^da^perti^lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădăpertĭlis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>adaperio</etym>, <sense id="n696.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that may be opened</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">latus hoc adapertile tauri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:3:11:46" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 3, 11, 46</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adapertio: <entryFree id="n697" type="main" key="a^da^perti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădăpertĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, an uncovering; hence, fig., <sense id="n697.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a revealing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">disclosure</hi> (late Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">legis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>August.</author> Quaest. 83, 61</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adapertus: <entryFree id="n698" type="main" key="a^da^pertus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădăpertus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of adaperio.</entryFree>
adaptatus: <entryFree id="n699" type="main" key="a^dapta_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădaptātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos> of adapto.</entryFree>
adapto: <entryFree id="n700" type="main" key="a^dapto"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-apto</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n700.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to fit</hi>, <hi rend="ital">adjust</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">adapt to a thing;</hi> with <case>dat.</case> only in <hi rend="ital">part. pass.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">galericulo capiti adaptato et annexo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=otho:12" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Oth. 12</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:33" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Claud. 33</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adaquo: <entryFree id="n701" type="main" key="a^da^quo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-ăquo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>aqua</etym>, <sense id="n701.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to bring water to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to give to drink</hi> (postAug.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:24:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 24, 46</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">29, 10</bibl>.—Of plants: <cit><quote lang="la">amygdalas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 10, 11, § 64</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vites,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 3, 33</bibl></cit>.—* In <hi rend="ital">pass.</hi>: adaquari (different from the foll.), <hi rend="ital">to be brought to drink</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">jumentum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=gal.:7" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Galb. 7</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adaquor: <entryFree id="n702" type="main" key="a^da^quor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-ăquor</orth>, <itype>ātus, 1</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos>, <sense id="n702.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to bring</hi> or <hi rend="ital">procure water for one's self</hi>, <hi rend="ital">io fetch water</hi>: nec sine periculo possent adaquari oppidani, Auct. B. G. 8, 41, where Dinter gives [<hi rend="ital">ad</hi>] <hi rend="ital">aquari;</hi> v. aquor.</sense></entryFree>
adarca: <entryFree id="n703" type="greek" key="a^darca"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădarca</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, and <orth extent="full" lang="la">ădarce</orth>, <itype>es</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)da/rkh, a)da/rkhs</foreign>, <sense id="n703.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a froth</hi> or <hi rend="ital">efflorescence deposited on sedge</hi>, etc., <hi rend="ital">forming a spongy growth</hi>, also called calamochnus; form <hi rend="ital">adarca</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:32:140" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 32, 10, 52, § 140</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:167" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 16, 36, 66, § 167</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:241" default="NO" valid="yes">20, 22, 88, § 241</bibl>: form <hi rend="ital">adarce</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> 3, 48, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 28, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Tard. 1:1" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Tard. 1, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adaresco: <entryFree id="n704" type="hapax" key="a^da_resco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-āresco</orth>, <itype>rui, 3</itype>, <sense id="n704.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. inch.</hi> [ad, <hi rend="ital">intens.</hi>], <hi rend="ital">to dry up</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ubi amurca adaruerit, vestimenta condito,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 98</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adariarius: <entryFree id="n705" type="main" key="a^da_ri^a_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădārĭārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>ad-ara</etym>, <sense id="n705.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">serving at the altar</hi>: MAGISTER ADARIARIVS, Burton, Inscr. p. 587.</sense></entryFree>
adaro: <entryFree id="n706" type="main" key="a^da^ro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-ăro</orth>, <itype>āre, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>ad, <hi rend="ital">intens.</hi></etym>, <sense id="n706.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to plough carefully</hi>: in an interpolation in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:23:1:section=2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 23, 1, § 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adasia: <entryFree id="n707" type="gloss" key="adasia"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adasia</orth> <itype>ovis vetula recentis partus</itype>, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=12" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 12</bibl> Müll.; Gloss. Mai Clas. Auct. viii. p. 52.</entryFree>
adaucto: <entryFree id="n708" type="main" key="a^daucto"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-aucto</orth>, <itype>āre, 1</itype>, <sense id="n708.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. freq.</hi> [adaugeo], <hi rend="ital">to augment much</hi>: rem summam et patriam nostram, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 75, 3</bibl> (R<bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Trag. Rel. p. 283</bibl>).</sense></entryFree>
adauctor: <entryFree id="n709" type="main" key="a^dauctor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-auctor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n709.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an augmenter</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> de Anim. 2</bibl>, where better <hi rend="ital">auctor.</hi></sense></entryFree>
adauctus: <entryFree id="n710" type="main" key="a^dauctus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădauctus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of adaugeo.</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n711" type="main" key="a^dauctus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădauctus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>adaugeo</etym>, <sense id="n711.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an increasing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">increase</hi>, <hi rend="ital">growth</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quaecunque vides hilaro grandescere adauctu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:1122" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 1122</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lunae (opp. defectio),</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sol.</author> 23 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
adaugeo: <entryFree id="n712" type="main" key="a^dauge^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-augĕo</orth>, <itype>xi, ctum, 2</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n712.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to make greater by adding to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to increase</hi>, <hi rend="ital">augment.</hi> </sense><sense id="n712.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">timet, ne tua duritia adaucta sit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:3:1:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 3, 1, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec maleficia aliis nefariis cumulant atque adaugent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:chapter=11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 11</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:1:3:4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Inv. 1, 3, 4</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 18</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 1, 5, 21</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 2, 25</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:22" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 22</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 4, 6 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi></bibl>—</sense><sense id="n712.2" n="II" level="1"> Esp., in sacrifices, t. t., <hi rend="ital">to devote</hi> (cf. augeo): <cit><quote lang="la">decumam esse adauctam tibi quam vovi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:2:2:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 2, 2, 62</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adaugesco: <entryFree id="n713" type="main" key="a^daugesco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-augesco</orth>, <itype>ĕre</itype>, <sense id="n713.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. inch. n.</hi> [ad, <hi rend="ital">intens.</hi>], <hi rend="ital">to begin to increase</hi> or <hi rend="ital">augment</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to grow</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to thrive</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque adaugescit quidquam neque deperit inde,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:296" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 296</bibl></cit>; so also Cic. <usg type="style">poet.</usg> in Div. 1, 7 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
adaxint: <entryFree id="n714" type="main" key="a^daxint"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădaxint</orth>, v. adigo <sense id="n714.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">init.</hi></sense></entryFree>
adbello: <entryFree id="n715" type="main" key="a^dbello"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-bello</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <sense id="n715.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to make war upon</hi> (late Lat.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 16, 9</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adbibo: <entryFree id="n716" type="main" key="adbi^bo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-bĭbo</orth>, <itype>bĭbi, bĭbĭtum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>ad, <hi rend="ital">intens.</hi></etym>, <sense id="n716.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to drink</hi> (not in Cic.). </sense><sense id="n716.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">quando adbibero,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:2:2:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 2, 2, 58</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:2:1:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 2, 1, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:2:22" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 2, 22</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n716.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, of discourse, <hi rend="ital">to drink in</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:Gl. 3:3:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. Gl. 3, 3, 10</bibl> (cf. devorare dicta, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:3:3:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> As. 3, 3, 59</bibl>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:3:5:14" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 3, 5, 14</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Carm. 16, 126</bibl>).—Hence of instruction, <hi rend="ital">to drink in eagerly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to listen to attentively</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc adbibe puro Pectore verba, puer,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 2, 67</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adbito: <entryFree id="n717" type="hapax" key="adbi_to"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-bīto</orth>, <itype>ĕre, 3</itype>, <sense id="n717.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v.n.</hi> [beto], <hi rend="ital">to come</hi> or <hi rend="ital">draw near</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to approach</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si adbites propius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:3:4:72" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 3, 4, 72</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adblatero: <entryFree id="n718" type="hapax" key="adbla^te^ro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-blătĕro</orth>, <itype>āre, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>ad, <hi rend="ital">intens.</hi></etym>, <sense id="n718.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to prattle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to chatter</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">affanias,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 9, p. 221, 25</bibl></cit> Elm.</sense></entryFree>
adc: <entryFree id="n719" type="main" key="adc"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adc</orth>., words beginning thus, v. in <orth extent="full" lang="la">acc</orth>.</entryFree>
addax: <entryFree id="n720" type="foreign" key="addax"><orth extent="full" lang="la">addax</orth>, <itype>ācis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (an African word, acc. to Plin., l. c.), <sense id="n720.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name of a wild</hi> <cb n="ADDI" /> <hi rend="ital">animal in Africa</hi>, <hi rend="ital">with crooked horns</hi>, Capra cervicapra, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:124" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 37, 45, § 124</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
addecet: <entryFree id="n721" type="main" key="adde^cet"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-dĕcet</orth>, <itype>ēre, 2</itype>, <sense id="n721.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. impers.</hi> [ad, <hi rend="ital">intens.</hi>], <hi rend="ital">it behooves</hi>, <hi rend="ital">it becomes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">it is fit</hi> or <hi rend="ital">proper that</hi> (used only in Enn. and Plaut., in the latter very often), constr. with <case>acc.</case> or with <case>acc.</case> and <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: sed virum virtute vera vivere animatum addecet, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:7:17:10" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 7, 17, 10</bibl> (Trag. v. 338, ed. Vahl.; R<bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:page=52" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> p. 52</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">ut matrem addecet familias,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:2:3:80" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. 2, 3, 80</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">meo me aequum est morigerum patri, ejus studio servire addecet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:3:4:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. 3, 4, 21</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">nam peculi probam nihil habere addecet Clam virum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:2:2:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cas. 2, 2, 26</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:1:2:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 1, 2, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:4:2:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 4, 2, 21</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:5:156" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 1, 5, 156</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1:2:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 1, 2, 41</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
addecimo: <entryFree id="n722" type="main" key="adde^ci^mo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-dĕcĭmo</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <sense id="n722.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to take by the tenth part</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to tithe</hi> (v. decimo): <cit><quote lang="la">vinearum reditus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,011:8:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 1 Reg. 8, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">greges vestros,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 8, 17</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
addenseo: <entryFree id="n723" type="main" key="addense^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-densĕo</orth>, <itype>ēre</itype>, and <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-denso</orth>, <itype>āre</itype> (cf. Wagner ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:248" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 248</bibl>), 2 and <itype>1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n723.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to make close</hi>, <hi rend="ital">compact</hi> (very rare): <cit><quote lang="la">extremi addensent acies,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:432" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 432</bibl></cit> Rib.—In <hi rend="ital">pass.</hi>, of water, <hi rend="ital">to become thick</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to thicken</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aquam radice ea addita addensari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:230" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 20, 21, 84, § 230</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
addico: <entryFree id="n724" type="main" key="addi_co"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-dīco</orth>, <itype>xi, ctum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> (<sense id="n724.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">imp.</hi> addice, for addic, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:2:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 2, 50</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">addixti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:12:16" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 12, 16</bibl></cit>), orig., <hi rend="ital">to give one's assent to a thing</hi> (“addicere est proprie idem dicere et approbare dicendo,” <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=13" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 13</bibl> Müll.), in its lit. signif. belonging only to augural and judicial language (opp. abdĭco). </sense><sense id="n724.1" n="I" level="1"> Of a favorable omen, <hi rend="ital">to be propitious to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to favor</hi>, usually with aves as subj., and without obj.: <cit><quote lang="la">cum sacellorum exaugurationes admitterent aves, in Termini fano non addixere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:55:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 55, 3</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">Fabio auspicanti aves semel atque iterum non addixerunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:16:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 27, 16, 15</bibl></cit>; also with auspicium as <hi rend="ital">subj.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">addicentibus auspiciis vocat contionem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 14</bibl></cit>; cf. Drak. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:36:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 36, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:16:15" default="NO" valid="yes">27, 16, 15</bibl>.—And with <case>acc.</case> of obj.: <cit><quote lang="la">illum quem aves addixerant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=241" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 241</bibl></cit> Müll.—In judicial lang.: alicui aliquid or aliquem, <hi rend="ital">to award</hi> or <hi rend="ital">adjudge any thing to one</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to sentence;</hi> hence Festus, with reference to the adjudged or condemned person, says: <cit><quote lang="la">“alias addicere damnare est,” p. 13 Müll.: ubi in jus venerit, addicet praetor familiam totam tibi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:1:1:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 1, 1, 57</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bona alicui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 52</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">addictus erat tibi?</quote> <trans><tr>had he been declared bound to you for payment?</tr></trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,003:14:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Com. 14, 41</bibl></cit>; hence ironic.: Fufidium . . . creditorem debitoribus suis addixisti, <hi rend="ital">you have adjudged the creditor to his debtors</hi> (instead of the reverse), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:chapter=35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 35</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">liberum corpus in servitutem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 56</bibl></cit>.—Hence <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>, <orth extent="full" lang="la">addictus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">one who has been given up</hi> or <hi rend="ital">made over as servant to his creditor</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ducite nos quo jubet, tamquam quidem addictos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:5:2:87" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 5, 2, 87</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">addictus Hermippo et ab hoc ductus est,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fl. 20</bibl></cit> <hi rend="ital">extr.;</hi> cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:15:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 6, 15, 20</bibl>. (The addictus, <hi rend="ital">bondman</hi>, was not properly a slave = <hi rend="ital">servus</hi>, for he retained his <hi rend="ital">nomen</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cognomen</hi>, his <hi rend="ital">tribus</hi>, which the <hi rend="ital">servus</hi> did not have; he could become free again by cancelling the demand, even against the will of his <hi rend="ital">dominus;</hi> the <hi rend="ital">servus</hi> could not; the <hi rend="ital">addictus</hi>, when set free, was also again <hi rend="ital">ingenuus</hi>, the <hi rend="ital">servus</hi> only <hi rend="ital">libertinus;</hi> v. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:7:3:27" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 7, 3, 27</bibl>. The inhuman law of the Twelve Tables, which, however, was never put in execution, that one indebted to several creditors should be cut in pieces and divided among them, is mentioned by <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:20:1" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 20, 1</bibl>: Niebuhr, Rom. Gesch. 1, 638; <cit><quote lang="la">Smith's Antiq.): addicere alicui judicium,</quote> <trans><tr>to grant one leave to bring an action</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 6:section=61" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 6, § 61</bibl></cit> Müll.: addicere litem, sc. judici, <hi rend="ital">to deliver a cause to the judge.</hi> This was the office of the praetor. Such is the purport of the law of XII. Tab. Tab. I.: POST MERIDIEM PRAESENTI STLITEM ADDICITO, ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:17:2" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 17, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">judicem or arbitrum (instead of dare judicium),</quote> <trans><tr>to appoint for one a judge in his suit</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:5:1:39:46" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 5, 1, 39, 46</bibl></cit> and 80: addicere aliquid in diem, <hi rend="ital">to adjudge a thing to one</hi> ad interim, so that, upon a change of circumstances, the matter in question shall be restored in integrum, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:18:2" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 18, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:6:1:41" default="NO">6, 1, 41</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:39:3:9" default="NO">39, 3, 9</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n724.2" n="B" level="2"> In auctions, <hi rend="ital">to adjudge to the highest bidder</hi>, <hi rend="ital">knock down</hi>, <hi rend="ital">strike off</hi>, <hi rend="ital">deliver to</hi> (with the price in <case>abl.</case>): ecquis est ex tanto populo, qui bona C. Rabirii Postumi<pb n="31" /> <cb n="ADDO" />  nummo sestertio sibi addici velit, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,030:chapter=17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rab. Post. 17</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 55</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:50" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 50</bibl>.—Addicere bona alicujus in publicum, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to confiscate</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 18</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">hence in Plaut., of a parasite, who strikes himself off, as it were, i. e. promises himself to one as guest, on condition that he does not in the mean time have a higher bid, i. e. is not attracted to another by a better table,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:1:2:76 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 1, 2, 76 sq.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n724.3" n="C" level="2"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">to sell</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to make over to</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">addice tuam mihi meretricem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:2:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 2, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hominem invenire neminem potuit, cui meas aedes addiceret, traderet, donaret, Auct. Or. pro Dom. 41. Antonius regna addixit pecunia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:7:5:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 7, 5, 15</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:5:109" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 5, 109</bibl>.—In a metaph. signif., </sense><sense id="n724.4" n="D" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To deliver</hi>, <hi rend="ital">yield</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">resign a thing to one</hi>, either in a good or a bad sense. </sense><sense id="n724.5" n="a" level="4"> In a good sense, <hi rend="ital">to devote</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to consecrate to</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">senatus, cui me semper addixi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:39:93" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Planc. 39, 93</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agros omnes addixit deae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:25" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 25</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">hence, morti addicere,</quote> <trans><tr>to devote to death</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:10:45" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 10, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nolite . . . omnem Galliam prosternere et perpetuae servituti addicere,</quote> <trans><tr>to devote to perpetual slavery</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:77" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 77</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n724.6" n="b" level="4"> In a bad sense, <hi rend="ital">to give up</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to sacrifice</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to abandon</hi> (very freq.); <cit><quote lang="la">ejus ipsius domum evertisti, cujus sanguinem addixeras,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:34:83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 34, 83</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">libidini cujusque nos addixit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:5:12:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 5, 12, 33</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:chapter=32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 32</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:chapter=17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sest. 17</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Quint. 30</bibl>; hence <usg type="style">poet.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid faciat? crudele, suos addicere amores,</quote> <trans><tr>to sacrifice</tr>, <tr>to surrender his love</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:617" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 617</bibl></cit> (where some read wrongly <hi rend="ital">abdicere</hi>).—</sense><sense id="n724.7" n="E" level="2"> In later Latin, <hi rend="ital">to attribute</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ascribe a work to one</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae (comoediae) nomini eius (Plauti) addicuntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:3:3:13" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 3, 3, 13</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">addic-tus</orth>, <pos>P. a.</pos> (after II. D.), <hi rend="ital">dedicated</hi> or <hi rend="ital">devoted to a thing;</hi> hence, </sense><sense id="n724.8" n="a" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Destined to</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">gladiatorio generi mortis addictus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:11:7:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 11, 7, 16</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:17:11" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 17, 11</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n724.9" n="b" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Given up to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bound to</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui certis quibusdam destinatisque sententiis quasi addicti et consecrati sunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:2:5" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 2, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nullius addictus jurare in verba magistri,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 1, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Prasinae factioni addictus et deditus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Cal. 55</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sup.</hi>, and <pos>adv.</pos> not used.</sense></entryFree>
addictio: <entryFree id="n725" type="main" key="addicti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">addictĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>addico</etym>, <sense id="n725.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the awarding</hi> or <hi rend="ital">adjudging</hi> (of the praetor or judge, v. addīco, B.): bonorum possessionumque addictio et condonatio, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 1, 4, 12</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1251,001:Inst. 3:section=189" default="NO"><author>Gai.</author> Inst. 3, § 189</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:40:5:4" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 40, 5, 4</bibl>, §§ 2, 5; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:49:14:50" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 49, 14, 50</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
addictus: <entryFree id="n726" type="main" key="addictus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">addictus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos> of addico.</entryFree>
addisco: <entryFree id="n727" type="main" key="addisco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-disco</orth>, <itype>dĭdĭci</itype>, no <sense id="n727.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">sup.</hi>, <itype>3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> </sense><sense id="n727.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To learn in addition to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to learn further</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quid? qui etiam addiscunt aliquid? ut Solonem versibus gloriantem videmus, qui se cotidie aliquid addiscentem senem fieri dicit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> de Sen. 8, 26</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:29" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 5, 29</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 3, 36</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:593 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 593 al.</bibl> (cf. addocere, <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 5, 18</bibl>).—</sense><sense id="n727.2" n="II" level="1"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">to learn</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be informed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to hear</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quos cum venire rex addidicisset, in fugam vertitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:2:3:13" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 2, 3, 13</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
additamentum: <entryFree id="n728" type="main" key="addi^ta_mentum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">addĭtāmentum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>addo</etym>, <sense id="n728.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an addition</hi>, <hi rend="ital">accession</hi>, <hi rend="ital">increase</hi>: inimicorum, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:31:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 31, 68</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">vitae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 17:6" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 17, 6</bibl></cit>: praeter nomen nihil est additamenti, Pseud.<bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:ad Caes. de Rep. Ord. 2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> ad Caes. de Rep. Ord. 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">pretii,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 9, 6</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
additicius: <entryFree id="n729" type="main" key="addi^ti_ci^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">addĭtīcĭus</orth> (not -tius), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n729.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">added</hi>, <hi rend="ital">annexed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">additional</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> de Rebus Carn. 52</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:50:16:98" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 50, 16, 98</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
additio: <entryFree id="n730" type="main" key="addi^ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">addĭtĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n730.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an adding to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">addition</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">figurarum additio et abjectio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:3:18" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 9, 3, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Sic corpori fit additio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Acut. 2:37" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Acut. 2, 37</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 978</bibl> P.</sense></entryFree>
addititius: <entryFree id="n731" type="main" key="addi^ti_ti^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">addĭtītĭus</orth>, v. additicius.</entryFree>
additivus: <entryFree id="n732" type="hapax" key="addi^ti_vus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">addĭtīvus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n732.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">added</hi>, <hi rend="ital">annexed;</hi> of the pronoun <hi rend="ital">ipse</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 1095</bibl> P.</sense></entryFree>
additus: <entryFree id="n733" type="main" key="addi^tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">addĭtus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos> of addo.</entryFree>
addivino: <entryFree id="n734" type="hapax" key="addi_vi_no"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-dīvīno</orth>, <itype>āre, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>ad <hi rend="ital">intens.</hi></etym>, <sense id="n734.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to divine</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to prognosticate</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quemdam ex facie hominum addivinantem, ex his dixisse futurae mortis annos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:88" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 10, 36, § 88</bibl></cit> dub. (Cod. Bamb. and Sillig: divinantem).</sense></entryFree>
addo: <entryFree id="n735" type="main" key="addo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-do</orth>, <itype>dĭdi, dĭtum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>2. do</etym> (addues for addideris, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=27" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 27</bibl> Müll.), <sense id="n735.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to put</hi>, <hi rend="ital">place</hi>, <hi rend="ital">lay</hi>, etc., <hi rend="ital">a person</hi> or <hi rend="ital">thing to another.</hi> </sense><sense id="n735.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen. </sense><sense id="n735.2" n="A" level="2"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, NEVE AVROM ADDITO, <hi rend="ital">let no gold be put into the grave with the dead</hi>, Fragm. of the XII.
