Tab. in <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> de Leg. 2, 24</bibl>: Argus, quem quondam Ioni Juno custodem addidit, Plaut. <cb n="ADDO" /> Aul. 3, 6, 20; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:2:6:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 2, 6, 69</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adimunt diviti, addunt pauperi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ter.</author> Ph. 2, 1, 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">spumantia addit Frena feris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:818" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 818</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Pergamaque Iliacamque jugis hanc addidit arcem, i.e. imposuit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 336</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:8:10" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 8, 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">flammae aquam,</quote> <trans><tr>to throw upon</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:2:4:42" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 2, 4, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">incendia ramis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:7:161" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 7, 161</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">propiorem Martem,</quote> <trans><tr>to bring nearer</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:5:442" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 5, 442</bibl></cit>.— With <hi rend="ital">in</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">uram in ollulas addere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:54:2" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 54, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">glandem in dolium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:ib. 3:15:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 15, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">eas epistulas in eundem fasciculum velim addas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:12:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 12, 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adde manus in vincla meas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:1:7:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 1, 7, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:2:672:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. A. 2, 672, 30</bibl>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum carceribus sese effudere quadrigae, addunt in spatia, i. e. dant se,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:513" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 513</bibl></cit>, v. Heyne and Forb.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n735.3" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to bring to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to add to;</hi> with <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pudicitiae hujus vitium me hinc absente'st additum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:2:2:179" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 2, 2, 179</bibl></cit>: fletum ingenio muliebri, Pac. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:21:50" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 21, 50</bibl>; also <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">operam addam sedulo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,007:1:1:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cist. 1, 1, 54</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:4:4:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pers. 4, 4, 57</bibl>: addere animum, or animos, <hi rend="ital">to give courage</hi>, <hi rend="ital">make courageous</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">mihi quidem addit animum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:3:2:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 3, 2, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed haec sunt in iis libris, quos tu laudando animos mihi addidisti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 2, 4</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">animos cum clamore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:388" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 388</bibl></cit>.—So also: <cit><quote lang="la">addis mihi alacritatem scribendi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:16:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 16, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">verba virtutem non addere,</quote> <trans><tr>impart</tr>, <tr>bestow</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 58</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">severitas dignitatem addiderat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:ib. 57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 57</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">audaciam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> J. 94</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">formidinem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:ib. 37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">metum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 62</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 76</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex ingenio suo quisque demat vel addat fidem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ardorem mentibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:184" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 184</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ductoribus honores,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 249</bibl></cit>; hence, addere alicui calcar, <hi rend="ital">to give one the spur</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to spur him on</hi>: anticipate atque addite calcar, Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 70, 13</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">vatibus addere calcar,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 217</bibl></cit> (cf.: admovere calcar <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 6, 1</bibl>, and adhibere calcar, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=56" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 56</bibl>).</sense><sense id="n735.4" n="II" level="1"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n735.5" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To add to by way of increase</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to join</hi> or <hi rend="ital">annex to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to augment</hi>, with <case>dat.</case> or <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> (the most common signif. of this word): <cit><quote lang="la">etiam fides, ei quae accessere, tibi addam dono gratiis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:3:4:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 3, 4, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">verbum adde etiam unum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:4:3:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 4, 3, 68</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:5:2:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 5, 2, 19</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">non satis habes quod tibi dieculam addo?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 2, 27</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:1:1:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 1, 1, 33</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ph. 1, 1, 8</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">illud in his rebus non addunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:900" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 900</bibl></cit>: quaeso ne ad malum hoc addas malum, Caec. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 154, 15</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">addendo deducendoque videre quae reliqui summa fiat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:18:59" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 18, 59</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 12 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:15:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 15, 20</bibl>; id <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0400,001:1:13" default="NO"><author>Att.</author> 1, 13</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">acervum efficiunt uno addito grano,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0400,001:Ac. 2:16:49" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 16, 49</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hunc laborem ad cotidiana opera addebant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 49</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">multas res novas in edictum addidit,</quote> <trans><tr>he made essential additions to</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Cat. 2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Cat. 2, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">eaque res multum animis eorum addidit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 75:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 75, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">addita est alia insuper injuria,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">novas litterarum formas addidit vulgavitque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:11:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 11, 13</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 14 al.</bibl>—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">noctem addens operi,</quote> <trans><tr>also the night to the work</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:411" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 411</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">ut quantum generi demas, virtutibus addas,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 20, 22</bibl></cit>.— With <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">additum ad caput legis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:40" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 40</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:1:13:17" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 1, 13, 17</bibl>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg> with <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ille viris pila et ferro circumdare pectus addiderat,</quote> <trans><tr>he instructed them in addition</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:8:550" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 8, 550</bibl></cit>: addere gradum (sc. gradui), <hi rend="ital">to add step to step</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to quicken one's pace</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adde gradum, appropera,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Plaut.</author> Tr. 4, 3, 3</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 27</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:9" default="NO" valid="yes">26, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:6:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 6, 20</bibl>; cf. Doed. Syn. 4, 58: addito tempore, <hi rend="ital">in course of time</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">conjugia sobrinarum diu ignorata addito tempore percrebuisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:12:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 12, 6</bibl></cit>; so also: addita aetate, <hi rend="ital">with increased age</hi>: in infantia scabunt aures; <cit><quote lang="la">quod addita aetate non queunt,</quote> <trans><tr>as they grow older</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:260" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 48, 108, § 260</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n735.6" n="2" level="3"> <usg type="dom">Mercant. t. t.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to add to</hi> one's bidding, <hi rend="ital">to give more</hi>: nihil addo, Poët. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:63:255" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 63, 255</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n735.7" n="B" level="2"> When a new thought is added to what precedes, as an enlargement of it, it is introduced by adde, adde huc, adde quod, and the like (cf. accedo), <hi rend="ital">add to this</hi>, <hi rend="ital">add to this the circumstance that</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">besides</hi>, <hi rend="ital">moreover</hi> . . .: <cit><quote lang="la">adde furorem animi proprium atque oblivia rerum, adde quod in nigras lethargi mergitur undas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:828 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 828 sq.</bibl></cit> (cf. the third verse before: <hi rend="ital">advenit</hi> id quod eam de rebus saepe futuris Macerat): <cit><quote lang="la">adde huc, si placet, unguentarios, saltatores totumque ludum talarium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:42:150" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 42, 150</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adde hos praeterea casus, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:8:71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 8, 71</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adde huc populationem agrorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 7, 30</bibl></cit>: adde quod pubes tibi crescit omnis, Hor. <cb n="ADDU" /> C. 2, 8, 17; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:Ep. 1:18:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 1, 18, 52</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adde quod ingenuas didicisse fideliter artes Emollit mores nec sinit esse feros,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Pont. 2, 9, 49</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adde huc quod mercem sine fucis gestat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Sat. 1, 2, 83</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adde super dictis quod non levius valeat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 7, 78</bibl></cit>.—So also when several are addressed, as in the speech of Scipic to his soldiers: <cit><quote lang="la">adde defectionem Italiae, Siciliae, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:41:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 41, 12</bibl></cit>.—Also with the <case>acc.</case> and <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">addebat etiam, se in legem Voconiam juratum contra eam facere non audere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:17:55" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 17, 55</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">and with an anticipatory dem. pron.: Addit etiam illud, equites non optimos fuisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:8:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Deiot. 8, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Addit haec, fortes viros sequi, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:35:96 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 35, 96 al.</bibl></cit>: addito as <hi rend="ital">abl. absol. with a subj. clause; with the addition</hi>, <hi rend="ital">with this addition</hi> (post-Aug.): vocantur patres, addito consultandum super re magna et atroci, <hi rend="ital">with this intimation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">that they were to consult</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 28</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">addito ut luna infra terram sit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 17, 18, § 62</bibl></cit> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">adjuncto ut ... haberentur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:12" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 12</bibl></cit>).— Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">addĭtus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos> (addo I.), <hi rend="ital">joined to one as a constant observer;</hi> so, </sense><sense id="n735.8" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Watching</hi> or <hi rend="ital">observing in a hostile</hi> or <hi rend="ital">troublesome manner</hi>: si mihi non praetor siet additus atque agitet me, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> Sat. 6, 4</bibl>.—Hence, in gen., </sense><sense id="n735.9" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Pursuing one incessantly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">persecuting</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec Teucris addita Juno Usquam aberit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:90" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 90</bibl></cit> Serv. (= adfixa, incumbens, infesta).</sense></entryFree>
addoceo: <entryFree id="n736" type="hapax" key="addo^ce^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-dŏcĕo</orth>, <itype>cui, ctum, 2</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n736.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to teach something in addition to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to teach</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ebrietas addocet artes,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 5, 18</bibl></cit> (but in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:37:104" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 37, 104</bibl>, the correct read. is adducti, B. and K.).</sense></entryFree>
addormio: <entryFree id="n737" type="hapax" key="addormi^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-dormĭo</orth>, <itype>īre, 4</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, <sense id="n737.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to begin to sleep</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to go to sleep</hi>: rursus addormiunt, Cael. Aurel. 1, 11, 38.</sense></entryFree>
addormisco: <entryFree id="n738" type="hapax" key="addormisco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-dormisco</orth>, <itype>ĕre</itype>, <sense id="n738.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. inch. n.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to go to sleep</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quoties post cibum addormisceret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:8" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 8</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
addua: <entryFree id="n739" type="main" key="Addu^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Addŭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <foreign lang="greek">*)adou/as</foreign> (cf. Weichert Poët. Lat. 180), <sense id="n739.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river in Upper Italy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">which flows into the Po near Cremona</hi>, <hi rend="ital">now Adde</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:103:106" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 103, 106</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:16:20 al" default="NO" valid="yes">3, 16, 20 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
addubanum: <entryFree id="n740" type="gloss" key="adduba_num"><orth extent="full" lang="la">addubānum</orth> = dubium, acc. to Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=21" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 21</bibl> Müll.</entryFree>
addubitatio: <entryFree id="n741" type="main" key="addu^bi^ta_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">addŭbĭtātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>addubito</etym>, <sense id="n741.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a doubting</hi>, a rhetor. fig., <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 5, p. 171</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:4:18" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 4, 18</bibl>, where <hi rend="ital">dubitatio</hi> is the better reading (B. and K.).</sense></entryFree>
addubito: <entryFree id="n742" type="main" key="addu^bi^to"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-dŭbĭto</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> and <sense id="n742.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a.</hi>, pr., <hi rend="ital">to incline to doubt</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to begin to doubt</hi> (in Cic. several times, but never in his orations). </sense><sense id="n742.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To be in doubt</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to doubt;</hi> constr. </sense><sense id="n742.2" n="(a)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">de</hi> or <hi rend="ital">in</hi> aliqua re: <cit><quote lang="la">de quo Panaetium addubitare dicebant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:46:118" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 46, 118</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">de legatis paululum addubitatum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in his addubitare turpissimum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:4:18" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 4, 18</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n742.3" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">pron.</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">num</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">ut addubitet, quid potius dicat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:chapter=40" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">addubitavi, num a Volumnio senatore esset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 7, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">an hoc inhonestum necne sit, addubites,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:4:124" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 4, 124</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 10</bibl>; cf. Drak. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:4:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 4, 7</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">illud addubitat, utrum, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,009:5:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Con. 5, 4</bibl></cit> (acc. to Br. ad h. l.: <hi rend="ital">to leave it undecided;</hi> cf. with dubitare, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:1" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 1</bibl>).—</sense><sense id="n742.4" n="(g)" level="5"> With <case>acc.</case>, <hi rend="ital">to be doubtful of a thing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to call in question</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si plus adipiscare, re explicata, boni, quam addubitata mali,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:24:83" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 24, 83</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:47:105" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 1, 47, 105</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n742.5" n="(d)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to hesitate</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aptare lacertos addubitat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:14:358" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 14, 358</bibl></cit>.—（<foreign lang="greek">e</foreign>) <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">eos ipsos addubitare coget doctissimorum hominum tanta dissentio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:6:14" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 6, 14</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:19:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 10, 19, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:2:19:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 2, 19, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adduco: <entryFree id="n743" type="main" key="addu_co"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-dūco</orth>, <itype>xi, ctum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> (adduce for adduc, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:1:3:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 1, 3, 15</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Ter.</author> Ph. 2, 1, 29</bibl>; Afr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 174, 32</bibl>: <sense id="n743.0" n="I" level="1"><cit><quote lang="la">adduxti for adduxisti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:4:6:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 4, 6, 15</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:4:7:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 4, 7, 24</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adduxe = adduxisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:4:4:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 4, 4, 3</bibl></cit>), <hi rend="ital">to lead to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to bring</hi> or <hi rend="ital">convey to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">draw to</hi> any place or to one's self (opp. abduco, q. v.; syn.: adfero, apporto, adveho, induco). </sense><sense id="n743.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">quaeso, quī possim animum bonum habere, qui te ad me adducam domum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:3:2:78" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 3, 2, 78</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ille alter venit, quem secum adduxit Parmenio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:4:4:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 4, 4, 27</bibl></cit>; Afr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 174, 32</bibl>: quos secum Mitylenis Cratippus adduxit, Cic. Fil. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:16:21:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 16, 21, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Demetrius Epimachum secum adduxit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:10:22:262" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 10, 22, 262</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad lenam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:5:2:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 5, 2, 65</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:3:1:193" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 3, 1, 193</bibl>: ad cenam, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 159, 25</bibl> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">abduxi ad cenam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 1, 2</bibl></cit> <pb n="32" /> <cb n="ADDU" /> 9): <cit><quote lang="la">adduxit ea ad Adam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:2:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 2, 19</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,002:14:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Marc. 14, 53</bibl>.—Or with a <hi rend="ital">local adv.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tu istos adduce intro,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:5:3:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 5, 3, 54</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quia te adducturam huc dixeras eumpse non eampse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:1:2:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Truc. 1, 2, 31</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:5:3:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 5, 3, 29</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adduc huc filium tuum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,003:9:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Luc. 9, 41</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n743.2" n="2" level="3"> In gen., without regard to the access. idea of accompanying, <hi rend="ital">to lead</hi> or <hi rend="ital">bring</hi> a person or thing <hi rend="ital">to</hi> a place, <hi rend="ital">to take</hi> or <hi rend="ital">conduct</hi> from one place <hi rend="ital">to</hi> another (of living beings which have the power of motion, while <hi rend="ital">affero</hi> is properly used of things: attuli hunc. <hi rend="ital">Pseud.</hi> Quid? attulisti? <hi rend="ital">Ca.</hi> Adduxi volui dicere, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:2:4:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 2, 4, 21</bibl>).—So of <hi rend="ital">conducting</hi> an army: <cit><quote lang="la">exercitum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aquam,</quote> <trans><tr>to lead to</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:chapter=14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cael. 14</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">in</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">gentes feras in Italiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:8:11:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 8, 11, 2</bibl></cit>; cf. Oud. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:4:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 4, 22</bibl>, and Auct. B. G. 8, 35: <cit><quote lang="la">in judicium adductus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:10:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 10, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adducta res in judicium est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:16:67" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 16, 67</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 17</bibl>.—With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">puero nutricem adducit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:5:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 5, 2, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui ex Gallia pueros venales isti adducebat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Quint. 6</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg> with <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Diae telluris ad oras applicor et dextris adducor litora remis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:598" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 598</bibl></cit> (cf. advertor oras Scythicas, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:5:649" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 649</bibl>, and Rudd. II. p. 327): <cit><quote lang="la">adducere ad populum, i. e. in judicium populi vocare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Agr. 2, 6</bibl></cit>.—Of a courtesan, <hi rend="ital">to procure</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">puero scorta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Dion, 5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Dion, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">paelicem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Fast. 3, 483</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg> also of a place, which is, as it were, <hi rend="ital">brought near.</hi> Thus Hor. in describing the attractions of his Sabine farm: dicas adductum propius frondere Tarentum, Ep. 1, 16, 11.—</sense><sense id="n743.3" n="B" level="2"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n743.4" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To bring</hi> a thing <hi rend="ital">to</hi> a destined place <hi rend="ital">by drawing</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pulling</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to draw</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pull to</hi> one's self: <cit><quote lang="la">tormenta eo graviores emissiones habent, quo sunt contenta atque adducta vehementius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:24" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adducto arcu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:507" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 507</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">adducta sagitta,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 9, 632</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">utque volat moles, adducto concita nervo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:357" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 357</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adducta funibus arbor corruit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:775" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 775</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">funem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 14</bibl></cit>: so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:3:700" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 3, 700</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">colla parvis lacertis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:6:625" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 6, 625</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">equos,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fast. 6, 586</bibl></cit>.—Hence trop.: <cit><quote lang="la">habenas amicitiae,</quote> <trans><tr>to tighten</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:13:45" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 13, 45</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:632" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 632</bibl>, and 1, 63.—</sense><sense id="n743.5" n="2" level="3"> Of the skin or a part of the body, <hi rend="ital">to draw up</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wrinkle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">contract</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adducit cutem macies,</quote> <trans><tr>wrinkles the skin</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:397" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 397</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sitis miseros adduxerat artus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:483" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 483</bibl></cit>; so, frontem (opp. remittere), <hi rend="ital">to contract</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">interrogavit, quae causa frontis tam adductae?</quote> <trans><tr>a brow so clouded?</tr></trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:3:13" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 10, 3, 13</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Benef. 1:1" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Benef. 1, 1</bibl>.</sense><sense id="n743.6" n="II" level="1"> Fig. </sense><sense id="n743.7" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To bring</hi> a person or thing <hi rend="ital">into</hi> a certain condition; with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> or <hi rend="ital">in</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">numquam animum quaesti gratiā ad malas adducam partīs,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:5:3:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 5, 3, 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rem adduci ad interregnum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad arbitrium alterius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 5, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad suam auctoritatem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:10:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Deiot. 10, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">numquam prius discessit, quam ad finem sermo esset adductus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,015:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Ep. 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">iambos ad umbilicum adducere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:14:8" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 14, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in discrimen extremum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:6:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 6, 7</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 45, 8</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">in summas angustias,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Quint. 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in invidiam falso crimine,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:20" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in necessitatem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vitam in extremum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:14:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 14, 61</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n743.8" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To bring</hi> or <hi rend="ital">lead one to</hi> a certain act, feeling, or opinion; <hi rend="ital">to prompt</hi>, <hi rend="ital">induce</hi>, <hi rend="ital">prevail upon</hi>, <hi rend="ital">persuade</hi>, <hi rend="ital">move</hi>, <hi rend="ital">incite to</hi> it; with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">ut</hi> (very freq. and class., and for the most part in a good sense; while <hi rend="ital">seducere</hi> and <hi rend="ital">inducere</hi> denote instigating or seducing to something bad, Herz. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 3</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">although there are exceptions, as the foll. examples show): ad misericordiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:5:2:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 5, 2, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad nequitiem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:3:3:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ad. 3, 3, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad iracundiam, ad fletum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:93:322" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 93, 322</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae causa ad facinus adduxit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:chapter=31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in metum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:chapter=24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mur. 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in summam exspectationem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:17" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in spem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 2, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in opinionem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in suspicionem alicui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Hann. 7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Hann. 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad paenitentiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,006:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Rom. 2, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 10, 19</bibl>.—With <hi rend="ital">gerund</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad suspicandum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Pr. Cons. 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad credendum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,009:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Con. 3</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">ut</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adductus sum officio, fide, misericordia, etc., ut onus hoc laboris mihi suscipiendum putarem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:chapter=2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 1, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nullo imbre, nullo frigore adduci, ut capite operto sit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> de Sen. 10</bibl></cit>: <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 1, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 3, 9</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">6, 10</bibl>, etc.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:6:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 6, 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:49 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 49 al.</bibl>—And <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> in <hi rend="ital">pass.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quibus rebus adductus ad causam accesserim demonstravi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:chapter=3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 1, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">his rebus adducti,</quote> <trans><tr>being induced</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">6, 10</bibl>.—With <hi rend="ital">quin</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adduci nequeo quin existimem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:21" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 21</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: <cb n="ADEO" /> facilius adducor ferre humana humanitus, Afr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 514, 20</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n743.9" n="C" level="2"> Adducor with <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>, or with <hi rend="ital">ut</hi> and <hi rend="ital">subj.</hi> = adducor ad credendum, <foreign lang="greek">pei/qomai</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">to be induced to believe</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ego non adducor, quemquam bonum ullam salutem putare mihi tanti fuisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:11:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 11, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut jam videar adduci, hanc quoque, quae te procrearit, esse patriam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 2, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">illud adduci vix possum, ut ... videantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:5:14" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 1, 5, 14</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 20, 55</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1341" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 1341</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">adductus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos> </sense><sense id="n743.10" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Drawn tight</hi>, <hi rend="ital">stretched</hi>, <hi rend="ital">strained</hi>, <hi rend="ital">contracted.</hi>—<usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">vultus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:68" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 68</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">frons in supercilia adductior,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Capitol.</author> Ver. 10</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:1:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 1, 16</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n743.11" n="B" level="2"> Of place, <hi rend="ital">narrow</hi>, <hi rend="ital">contracted</hi>, <hi rend="ital">strait</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">(Africa) ex spatio paulatim adductior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:1:4" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 1, 4</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n743.12" n="C" level="2"> Of character, <hi rend="ital">strict</hi>, <hi rend="ital">serious</hi>, <hi rend="ital">severe</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">modo familiaritate juvenili Nero et rursus adductus, quasi seria consociaret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:14:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 14, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adductum et quasi virile servitium,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 12, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vis pressior et adductior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:1:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 1, 16</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi> not used.—<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi> only in <hi rend="ital">comp.</hi> <orth extent="full" lang="la">adductĭus</orth>, </sense><sense id="n743.13" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">More tightly</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adductius contorquere jacula,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Grat. Act. 27</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n743.14" n="2" level="3"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">more strictly</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">imperitare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">regnari,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Germ. 43</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adductius: <entryFree id="n744" type="main" key="adducti^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adductĭus</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. adductus <sense id="n744.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
adductor: <entryFree id="n745" type="main" key="adductor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adductor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n745.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a procurer</hi> (cf. adduco, 1. 2. <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>), Petr. Afran. ap. Meyer, Anthol. II. p. 27.</sense></entryFree>
adductus: <entryFree id="n746" type="main" key="adductus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adductus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos> of adduco.</entryFree>
adedo: <entryFree id="n747" type="main" key="a^de^do"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-ĕdo</orth>, <itype>ēdi, ēsum</itype> (less correctly, adessum), <itype>3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> (adest = adedit, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:6:265" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 6, 265</bibl>; cf. ĕdo), <sense id="n747.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to begin to eat</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to bite</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to nibble at</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to gnaw</hi>, etc.—As <hi rend="ital">verb finite</hi> very rare, and mostly <usg type="style">poet.</usg>; not found in prose of Cic. </sense><sense id="n747.1" n="I" level="1"> Prop.: <cit><quote lang="la">angues duo ex occulto allapsi adedere jecur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:16:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 25, 16, 2</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">adeso jecinore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:1:6:8" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 1, 6, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">favos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:242" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 242</bibl></cit>.—Hence metaph. of fire: <cit><quote lang="la">cum me supremus adederit ignis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:1:15:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 1, 15, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">flamma plurima postibus haesit adesis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:537" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 537</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n747.2" n="II" level="1"> In an enlarged sense (as a consequence of a continued biting, gnawing, etc.; and hence only in the <hi rend="ital">perf.</hi> or <hi rend="ital">part. pass.;</hi> cf.: accīdo, absumo, abrumpo), <hi rend="ital">to eat up</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to consume entirely</hi>: frumento adeso, quod ex areis in oppidum portatum est, Sisenn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 70, 32</bibl>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">extis adesis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:7:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 7, 13</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">pisces ex parte adesi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:3:90" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 6, 3, 90</bibl></cit>: and metaph., <hi rend="ital">to use up</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to consume</hi>, <hi rend="ital">waste</hi> (as money, strength, etc.): <cit><quote lang="la">non adesa jam, sed abundante etiam pecunia,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Quint. 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adesis fortunis omnibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:13:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 13, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bona adesa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 1, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adesus cladibus Asdrubal,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:13:680" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 13, 680</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ădēsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">eaten</hi>, <hi rend="ital">gnawed;</hi> hence <usg type="style">poet.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">worn away</hi>, esp. <hi rend="ital">by water</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adesi lapides,</quote> <trans><tr>smooth</tr>, <tr>polished</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:29:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 29, 36</bibl></cit> (after Theocr. 22, 49; <foreign lang="greek">ou(\s potamo\s perie/cese</foreign>): <cit><quote lang="la">scopulus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:10:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 10, 26</bibl></cit>: sale durus adeso caseus, <usg type="style">poet.</usg> for <hi rend="ital">sale adesus caseus</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Verg.</author> Mor. 98</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adelphi: <entryFree id="n748" type="main" key="A^delphi"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ădelphi</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">oe</orth>), <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)delfoi/</foreign>, <sense id="n748.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">The Brothers</hi>, a comedy of Terence.</sense></entryFree>
adelphis: <entryFree id="n749" type="main" key="a^delphi^s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădelphĭs</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym><foreign lang="greek">a)delfh/</foreign>, sister; so called as resembling the <hi rend="ital">caryotis</hi>, or because they hung two together from a branch</etym>, <sense id="n749.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kind of date</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:13:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 13, 4, 9, § 45</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ademptio: <entryFree id="n750" type="main" key="a^dempti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădemptĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>adimo</etym>, <sense id="n750.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a taking away</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a seizure</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">civitatis, Auct. Or. pro Dom. 30: bonorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">provinciae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 2, 76</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ademptor: <entryFree id="n751" type="main" key="a^demptor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădemptor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n751.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one who takes away</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">vitae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:in Joann. Tract. 116" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> in Joann. Tract. 116</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ademptus: <entryFree id="n752" type="main" key="a^demptus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădemptus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of adimo.</entryFree>
adeo: <entryFree id="n753" type="main" key="a^de^o1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-ĕo</orth>, <itype>ĭī, and rarely īvi, ĭtum</itype> (arch. adirier for adiri, <bibl default="NO"><author>Enn.</author> Rib. Trag. p. 59</bibl>), <itype>4</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> and <sense id="n753.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a.</hi> (acc. to Paul. ex Fest. should be accented a/deo; v. Fest. s. v. adeo, p. 19 Müll.; cf. the foll. word), <hi rend="ital">to go to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">approach</hi> a person or thing (syn.: accedo, aggredior, advenio, appeto). </sense><sense id="n753.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n753.2" n="A" level="2"> In gen., constr. </sense><sense id="n753.3" n="(a)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> (very freq.): sed tibi cautim est adeundum ad virum, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 512, 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque eum ad me adire neque me magni pendere visu'st,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Plaut.</author> Cur. 2, 2, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adeamne ad eam?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:4:1:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 4, 1, 15</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:3:5:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 3, 5, 30</bibl>: aut ad consules aut ad te aut ad Brutum adissent, Cic. Fragm. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 208, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad M. Bibulum adierunt, id. Fragm. ap. Arus. p. 213 Lind.: ad aedi\s nostras nusquam adiit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:1:1:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 1, 1, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adibam ad istum fundum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Caec. 29</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n753.4" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">in</hi>: priusquam Romam atque in horum conventum adiretis, Cic. <cb n="ADEO" /> Verr. 2, 4, 11, § 26 ed. Halm.—Esp.: adire in jus, <hi rend="ital">to go to law</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum ad praetorem in jus adissemus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:section=147" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 4, § 147</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:11:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 11, 24</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:87" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 87</bibl>, and in the Plebiscit. de Thermens. lin. 42: QVO DE EA RE IN IOVS ADITVM ERIT, cf. Dirks., Versuche S. p. 193.—</sense><sense id="n753.5" n="(g)" level="5"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">adeunt, consistunt, copulantur dexteras,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:1:2:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 1, 2, 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">eccum video: adibo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:7:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 5, 7, 5</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n753.6" n="(d)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne Stygeos adeam non libera manes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:465" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 465</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">voces aetherias adiere domos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:6:253" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 6, 253</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">castrorum vias,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">municipia,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">provinciam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:47" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non poterant adire eum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,003:8:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Luc. 8, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Graios sales carmine patrio,</quote> <trans><tr>to attain to</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Verg.</author> Cat. 11, 62</bibl></cit>; so with <hi rend="ital">latter supine</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">planioribus aditu locis,</quote> <trans><tr>places easier to approach</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 33</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">local adv.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quoquam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">huc,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:2:7:60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 2, 7, 60</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n753.7" n="B" level="2"> Esp., </sense><sense id="n753.8" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To approach one</hi> for the purpose of addressing, asking aid, consulting, and the like, <hi rend="ital">to address</hi>, <hi rend="ital">apply to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">consult</hi> (diff. from aggredior, q. v.). —Constr. with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> or oftener with <hi rend="ital">acc.;</hi> hence also <hi rend="ital">pass.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quanto satius est, adire blandis verbis atque exquaerere, sintne illa, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:5:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 1, 5, 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquot me adierunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:3:3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 3, 3, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adii te heri de filia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:2:2:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Hec. 2, 2, 9</bibl></cit>: cum pacem peto, cum placo, cum adeo, et cum appello meam, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 237, 28</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad me adire quosdam memini, qui dicerent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 3, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">coram adire et alloqui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 4, 65</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Pass.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aditus consul idem illud responsum retulit,</quote> <trans><tr>when applied to</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 37, 6 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque praetores adiri possent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:1:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 1, 2, 5</bibl></cit>.—Hence: adire aliquem per epistulam, <hi rend="ital">to address one in writing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">by a letter</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">per epistulam, aut per nuntium, quasi regem, adiri eum aiunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:4:6:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 4, 6, 9</bibl></cit> and 10; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 39</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 1, 9</bibl>.—So also: adire deos, aras, deorum sedes, etc., <hi rend="ital">to approach the gods</hi>, <hi rend="ital">their altars</hi>, etc., <hi rend="ital">as a suppliant</hi> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">acced. ad aras,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1199" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 1199</bibl></cit>): quoi me ostendam? quod templum adeam? Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 281, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut essent simulacra, quae venerantes deos ipsos se adire crederent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:27" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adii Dominum et deprecatus sum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,033:8:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Sap. 8, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aras,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:14:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 14, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sedes deorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:5:39" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 1, 5, 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">libros Sibyllinos,</quote> <trans><tr>to consult the Sibylline Books</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 34, 55</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 76</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">oracula,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:82" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 82</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n753.9" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To go to</hi> a thing in order to examine it, <hi rend="ital">to visit</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">oppida castellaque munita,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 94</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hiberna,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 52</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n753.10" n="3" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To come up to</hi> one in a hostile manner, <hi rend="ital">to assail</hi>, <hi rend="ital">attack</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem: nunc prior adito tu, ego in insidiis hic ero,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ter.</author> Ph. 1, 4, 52</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec quisquam ex agmine tanto audet adire virum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:379" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 379</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Servilius obvia adire arma jubetur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:9:272" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 9, 272</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n753.11" n="II" level="1"> Fig. </sense><sense id="n753.12" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To go to</hi> the performance of any act, <hi rend="ital">to enter upon</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to undertake</hi>, <hi rend="ital">set about</hi>, <hi rend="ital">undergo</hi>, <hi rend="ital">submit to</hi> (cf.: accedo, aggredior, and adorior).—With <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> or the <case>acc.</case> (class.): <cit><quote lang="la">nunc eam rem vult, scio, mecum adire ad pactionem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:2:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 2, 2, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tum primum nos ad causas et privatas et publicas adire coepimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=90" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 90</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adii causas oratorum, id. Fragm. Scaur. ap. Arus. p. 213 Lind.: adire ad rem publicam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> de Imp. Pomp. 24, 70</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad extremum periculum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 7</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">periculum capitis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:chapter=38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">laboribus susceptis periculisque aditis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:19" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in adeundis periculis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 24</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">adeundae inimicitiae, subeundae saepe pro re publica tempestates,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:66:139" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sest. 66, 139</bibl></cit>: ut vitae periculum aditurus videretur, Auct. B. G. 8, 48: maximos labores et summa pericula. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,020:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Timol. 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnem fortunam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 25, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dedecus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">servitutem voluntariam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">invidiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 4, 70</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gaudia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:5:39" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 1, 5, 39</bibl></cit>.—Hence of an inheritance, t. t., <hi rend="ital">to enter on</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum ipse hereditatem patris non adisses,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 2, 16</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,016:chapter=5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Arch. 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:8" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 8</bibl> and Dig.; <cit><quote lang="la">hence also: adire nomen,</quote> <trans><tr>to assume the name bequeathed by will</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:60" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 60</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n753.13" n="B" level="2"> Adire manum alicui, prov., <hi rend="ital">to deceive one</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to make sport of</hi> (the origin of this phrase is unc.; Acidalius conjectures that it arose from some artifice practised in wrestling, Wagner ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:8:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 2, 8, 8</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">eo pacto avarae Veneri pulcre adii manum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:2:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 2, 11</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:8:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Aul. 2, 8, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:5:2:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cas. 5, 2, 54</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:5:2:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pers. 5, 2, 18</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n754" type="main" key="a^de^o_^2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-ĕō^</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>cf. quoad and adhuc</etym> (acc. to Festus, it should be accented adéo, <sense id="n754.0" n="I" level="1"><xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">the preced. word</ref></xr>; but this distinction is merely a later invention of the grammarians; <pb n="33" /> <cb n="ADEO" /> cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:7:7" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 7, 7</bibl>). </sense><sense id="n754.1" n="I" level="1"> In the ante-class. per., </sense><sense id="n754.2" n="A" level="2"> To designate the limit of space or time, with reference to the distance passed through; hence often accompanied by usque (cf. ad), <hi rend="ital">to this</hi>, <hi rend="ital">thus far</hi>, <hi rend="ital">so far</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as far.</hi> </sense><sense id="n754.3" n="1" level="3"> Of space: <cit><quote lang="la">surculum artito usque adeo, quo praeacueris,</quote> <trans><tr>fit in the scion as far as you have sharpened it</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 40, 3</bibl></cit>.— Hence: res adeo rediit, <hi rend="ital">the affair has gone so far</hi> (viz., in deterioration, “cum aliquid pejus exspectatione contigit,” Don. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Ter.</author> Ph. 1, 2, 5</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">postremo adeo res rediit: adulescentulus saepe eadem et graviter audiendo victus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:1:1:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 1, 1, 61</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ph. 1, 2, 5</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n754.4" n="2" level="3"> Of time, <hi rend="ital">so long</hi> (<hi rend="ital">as</hi>), <hi rend="ital">so long</hi> (<hi rend="ital">till</hi>), strengthened by <hi rend="ital">usque</hi>, and with <hi rend="ital">dum</hi>, <hi rend="ital">donec</hi>, following, and in Cic. with <hi rend="ital">quoad</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">merces vectatum undique adeo dum, quae tum haberet, peperisset bona,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:1:1:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. 1, 1, 76</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">3, 4, 72</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:2:10 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. 1, 2, 10 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nusquam destitit instare, suadere, orare, usque adeo donec perpulit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:4:1:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 4, 1, 36</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 67</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 76</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">atque hoc scitis omnes usque adeo hominem in periculo fuisse, quoad scitum sit Sestium vivere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:38:82" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 38, 82</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n754.5" n="B" level="2"> For the purpose of equalizing two things in comparison, followed by <hi rend="ital">ut: in the same degree</hi> or <hi rend="ital">measure</hi> or <hi rend="ital">proportion . . . in which;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">so very</hi>, <hi rend="ital">so much</hi>, <hi rend="ital">so</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to such a degree ... as</hi> (only in comic poets), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:4:1:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 4, 1, 38</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adeon hominem esse invenustum aut infelicem quemquam, ut ego sum?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:5:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 5, 10</bibl></cit>.—Also followed by <hi rend="ital">quasi</hi>, when the comparison relates to similarity: <cit><quote lang="la">gaudere adeo coepit, quasi qui cupiunt nuptias,</quote> <trans><tr>in the same manner as those rejoice who desire marriage</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:5:1:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 5, 1, 12</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n754.6" n="C" level="2"> (Only in the comic poets) = ad haec, praeterea, <hi rend="ital">moreover</hi>, <hi rend="ital">besides</hi>, <hi rend="ital">too</hi>: ibi tibi adeo lectus dabitur, ubi tu haud somnum capias (<hi rend="ital">beside the other annoyances</hi>), <hi rend="ital">a bed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">too</hi>, <hi rend="ital">shall be given you there</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:2:80" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 1, 2, 80</bibl>.—Hence also with <hi rend="ital">etiam</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adeo etiam argenti faenus creditum audio,</quote> <trans><tr>besides too</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:3:1:101" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 3, 1, 101</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n754.7" n="D" level="2"> (Only in the comic poets.) Adeo ut, <hi rend="ital">for this purpose that</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to the end that</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">id ego continuo huic dabo, adeo me ut hic emittat manu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:5:3:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 5, 3, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">id adeo te oratum advenio, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:4:10:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Aul. 4, 10, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adeo ut tu meam sententiam jam jam poscere possis, faciam, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 2, 26</bibl></cit> (where Wagner now reads <hi rend="ital">at ut</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">atque adeo ut scire possis, factum ego tecum hoc divido,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:5:4:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Stich. 5, 4, 15</bibl></cit>. (These passages are so interpreted by Hand, I. p. 138; others regard adeo here = <hi rend="ital">quin immo.</hi>）—</sense><sense id="n754.8" n="E" level="2"> In narration, in order to put one person in strong contrast with another. It may be denoted by a stronger emphasis upon the word to be made conspicuous, or by <hi rend="ital">yet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on the contrary</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">jam ille illuc ad erum cum advenerit, narrabit, etc.: ille adeo illum mentiri sibi credet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:2:4 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 2, 4 sq.</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:2:1:8 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Merc. 2, 1, 8 al.</bibl></sense><sense id="n754.9" n="II" level="1"> To the Latin of every period belongs the use of this word, </sense><sense id="n754.10" n="A" level="2"> To give emphasis to an idea in comparison, <hi rend="ital">so</hi>, <hi rend="ital">so much</hi>, <hi rend="ital">so very</hi>, with verbs, adjectives, and substantives: <cit><quote lang="la">adeo ut spectare postea omnīs oderit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:prol. 65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. prol. 65</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">neminem quidem adeo infatuare potuit, ut ei nummum ullum crederet,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fl. 20, 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adeoque inopia est coactus Hannibal, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:32:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 22, 32, 3</bibl></cit> Weiss.: <cit><quote lang="la">et voltu adeo modesto, adeo venusto, ut nil supra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:1:92" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 1, 92</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nemo adeo ferus est, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 1, 39</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">usque</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adeo ego illum cogam usque, ut mendicet meus pater,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:3:4:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 3, 4, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">usque adeo turbatur,</quote> <trans><tr>even so much</tr>, <tr>so continually</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:1:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 1, 12</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:10:1:42" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 10, 1, 42</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:1:366" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 1, 366</bibl>.—In questions: <cit><quote lang="la">adeone me fuisse fungum, ut qui illi crederem?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:2:3:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 2, 3, 49</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adeone hospes hujus urbis, adeone ignarus es disciplinae consuetudinisque nostrae, ut haec nescias?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rab. 10, 28</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:7:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 2, 7, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 9, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:7:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 7, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:6:4" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 6, 4</bibl>.—With a negative in both clauses, also with <hi rend="ital">quin</hi> in the last: <cit><quote lang="la">non tamen adeo virtutum sterile saeculum, ut non et bona exempla prodiderit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 3</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=otho:9" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Oth. 9</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">verum ego numquam adeo astutus fui, quin, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:2:2:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 2, 2, 13</bibl></cit>.— <cit><quote lang="la">Sometimes the concluding clause is to be supplied from the first: quis genus Aeneadum, quis Trojae nesciat urbem? ... non obtusa adeo gestamus pectora Poeni, viz.,</quote> <trans><tr>that we know not the Trojans and their history</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:565" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 565</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adeo senuerunt Juppiter et Mars?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:6:59" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 6, 59</bibl></cit>.—Hence (post-Cic.): <cb n="ADEO" /> adeo non ut ... adeo nihil ut ... <hi rend="ital">so little that</hi>, <hi rend="ital">so far from that</hi> ... (in reference to which, it should be noticed that in Latin the negative is blended with the verb in one idea, which is qualified by <hi rend="ital">adeo</hi>) = tantum abest ut: haec dicta adeo nihil moverunt quemquam, ut legati prope violati sint, <hi rend="ital">these words left them all so unmoved that</hi>, etc., or <hi rend="ital">had so little effect</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:2:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 2, 7</bibl>: qui adeo non tenuit iram, ut gladio cinctum in senatum venturum se esse palam diceret, <hi rend="ital">who restrained his anger so little that</hi>, etc. (for, qui non—tenuit iram adeo, ut), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:7:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 8, 7, 5</bibl>; so 5, 45, 4; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:66:4" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 66, 4</bibl>: <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:3:12:22" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 3, 12, 22</bibl>.—Also with <hi rend="ital">contra</hi> in the concluding clause: <cit><quote lang="la">apud hostes Afri et Carthaginienses adeo non sustinebant, ut contra etiam pedem referrent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:34:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 30, 34, 5</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n754.11" n="B" level="2"> Adeo is placed enclitically after its word, like <hi rend="ital">quidem</hi>, <hi rend="ital">certe</hi>, and the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">ge\</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">even</hi>, <hi rend="ital">indeed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">just</hi>, <hi rend="ital">precisely.</hi> So, </sense><sense id="n754.12" n="1" level="3"> Most freq. with pronouns, in order to render prominent something before said, or foll., or otherwise known (cf. in Gr. <foreign lang="greek">e)/gwge, su/ge, au)to/s ge</foreign>, etc., Viger. ed. Herm. 489, vi. and Zeun.): argentariis male credi qui aiunt, nugas praedicant: nam et bene et male credi dico; id adeo hodie ego expertus sum, <hi rend="ital">just this</hi> (<foreign lang="greek">tou=to/ ge</foreign>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:5:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 5, 3, 1</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:4:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Aul. 2, 4, 10</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 2, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:98" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. 1, 1, 98</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 2, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:1:1:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 1, 1, 51</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 2, 31</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 2, 40</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:1:2:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Poen. 1, 2, 57</bibl>: plerique homines, quos, cum nihil refert, pudet; <cit><quote lang="la">ubi pudendum'st ibi eos deserit pudor, is adeo tu es,</quote> <trans><tr>you are just such a one</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:2:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cui tu obsecutus, facis huic adeo injuriam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:4:4:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 4, 4, 68</bibl></cit>: tute adeo jam ejus verba audies, <hi rend="ital">you yourself shall hear what he has to say</hi> (<foreign lang="greek">su/ge a)kou/sh|</foreign>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:3:3:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 3, 3, 27</bibl>: Dolabella tuo nihil scito mihi esse jucundius: hanc adeo habebo gratiam illi, i. e. hanc, quae maxima est, gratiam (<foreign lang="greek">tau/thn ge th\n xa/rin</foreign>), Caes. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:9:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 9, 16</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec adeo ex illo mihi jam speranda fuerunt,</quote> <trans><tr>even this</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:275" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 275</bibl></cit>.—It is often to be translated by the intensive <hi rend="ital">and</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and just</hi>, etc. (so esp. in Cic. and the histt.): id adeo, si placet, considerate, <hi rend="ital">just that</hi> (<foreign lang="greek">tou=to/ ge skopei=te</foreign>), <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Caec. 30, 87</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">id adeo ex ipso senatus consulto cognoscite,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:64:143" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 64, 143</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:30:80" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 30, 80</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad hoc quicumque aliarum atque senatus partium erant, conturbari remp., quam minus valere ipsi malebant.
