Id adeo malum multos post annos in civitatem reverterat,</quote> <trans><tr>And just this evil</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 37:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 37, 11</bibl></cit>; so 37, 2; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 68:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> J. 68, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:29:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 29, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes">4, 2, 2</bibl>: id adeo manifestum erit, si cognoverimus, etc., <hi rend="ital">and this</hi>, <hi rend="ital">precisely this</hi>, <hi rend="ital">will be evident</hi>, <hi rend="ital">if</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:16:18" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 16, 18</bibl> Spald.—It is rarely used with <hi rend="ital">ille</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ille adeo illum mentiri sibi credet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 2, 6</bibl></cit>.—Sometimes with the <hi rend="ital">rel. pron.</hi>: quas adeo haud quisquam liber umquam tetigit, Plaut: Poen. 1, 2, 57; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:12:37" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 12, 37</bibl>. —With <hi rend="ital">interrog. pron.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quis adeo tam Latinae linguae ignarus est, quin, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:7:17" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 7, 17</bibl></cit>.—Adeo is joined with the pers. pron. when the discourse passes from one person to another, and attention is to be particularly directed to the latter: Juppiter, tuque adeo summe Sol, qui res omnes inspicis, <hi rend="ital">and thou especially</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and chiefly thou</hi>, Enn. ap. Prob.: <cit><quote lang="la">teque adeo decus hoc aevi inibit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:4:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 4, 11</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 1, 24</bibl>: teque, Neptune, invoco, vosque adeo venti, Poët. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:34:73" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 34, 73</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">and without the copulative: vos adeo . . . item ego vos virgis circumvinciam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:3:4:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 3, 4, 25</bibl></cit>.— Ego adeo often stands for ego quidem, equidem (<foreign lang="greek">e)/gwge</foreign>): <cit><quote lang="la">tum libertatem Chrysalo largibere: ego adeo numquam accipiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:4:7:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 4, 7, 30</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:4:4:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 4, 4, 55</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:4:3:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Truc. 4, 3, 73</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ego adeo hanc primus inveni viam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:2:2:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 2, 2, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec me adeo fallit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 96</bibl></cit>.—Ipse adeo (<foreign lang="greek">au)to/s ge</foreign>), for the sake of emphasis: <cit><quote lang="la">atque hercle ipsum adeo contuor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:2:3:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 2, 3, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ipsum adeo praesto video cum Davo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:2:5:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 2, 5, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ipse adeo senis ductor Rhoeteus ibat pulsibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:14:487" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 14, 487</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n754.13" n="2" level="3"> With the <hi rend="ital">conditional conjj.</hi> si, nisi, etc. (Gr. <foreign lang="greek">ei)/ ge</foreign>), <hi rend="ital">if indeed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">if truly</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihili est autem suum qui officium facere immemor est, nisi adeo monitus,</quote> <trans><tr>unless</tr>, <tr>indeed</tr>, <tr>he is reminded of it</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:4:7:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 4, 7, 2</bibl></cit>: <hi rend="ital">Si.</hi> Num illi molestae quippiam hae sunt nuptiae? <hi rend="ital">Da.</hi> Nihil Hercle: aut si adeo, bidui est aut tridui haec sollicitudo, <hi rend="ital">and if</hi>, <hi rend="ital">indeed</hi>, etc. (not <hi rend="ital">if also</hi>, for also is implied in aut), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:2:6:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 2, 6, 7</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n754.14" n="3" level="3"> With <hi rend="ital">adverbs</hi>: nunc adeo (<foreign lang="greek">nu=n ge</foreign>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:3:1:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 3, 1, 29</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:2:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 2, 2, 4</bibl>; <cb n="ADEO" /> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:2:2:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Merc. 2, 2, 57</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:1:2:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. 1, 2, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:2:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 1, 2, 52</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:3:4:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 3, 4, 23</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:4:5:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 4, 5, 26</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:156" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 156</bibl>: jam adeo (<foreign lang="greek">dh/ ge</foreign>), <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 268</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:1:20" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 1, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:12:534" default="NO">12, 534</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:3:70" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 3, 70</bibl>. umquam adeo, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:5:4:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 5, 4, 23</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">inde adeo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:1:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 1, 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hinc adeo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:9:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 9, 59</bibl></cit>: sic adeo (<foreign lang="greek">ou(/tws ge</foreign>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:533" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 4, 533</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:12:646" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 12, 646</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">vix adeo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:498" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 498</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non adeo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:1:1:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 1, 1, 57</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:436" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 436</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n754.15" n="4" level="3"> With <hi rend="ital">adjectives</hi> = vel, <hi rend="ital">indeed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">even</hi>, <hi rend="ital">very</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fully</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quot adeo cenae, quas deflevi, mortuae!</quote> <trans><tr>how very many suppers</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:1:3:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 1, 3, 59</bibl></cit>: quotque adeo fuerint, qui temnere superbum ... Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 180, 2</bibl>: nullumne malorum finem adeo poenaeque dabis (adeo separated from nullum by <usg type="style">poet.</usg> license)? <hi rend="ital">wilt thou make no end at all to calamity and punishment?</hi> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:4:63" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 4, 63</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">trīs adeo incertos caeca caligine soles erramus,</quote> <trans><tr>three whole days we wander about</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:203" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 203</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">7, 629</bibl>.—And with <hi rend="ital">comp.</hi> or the <hi rend="ital">adv. magis</hi>, <hi rend="ital">multo</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">quae futura et quae facta, eloquar: multo adeo melius quam illi, cum sim Juppiter,</quote> <trans><tr>very much better</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:5:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 5, 2, 3</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:2:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Truc. 2, 1, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">magis adeo id facilitate quam aliā ullā culpā meā, contigit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:4:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 4, 15</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n754.16" n="5" level="3"> With the <hi rend="ital">conjj. sive</hi>, <hi rend="ital">aut</hi>, <hi rend="ital">vel</hi>, in order to annex a more important thought, or to make a correction, <hi rend="ital">or indeed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">or rather</hi>, <hi rend="ital">or even only</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">sive qui ipsi ambīssent, seu per internuntium, sive adeo aediles perfidiose quoi duint,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:prol. 71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. prol. 71</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si hercle scivissem, sive adeo joculo dixisset mihi, se illam amare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:5:4:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Merc. 5, 4, 33</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:4:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Truc. 4, 3, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:5:2:74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. 5, 2, 74</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:4:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 4, 1, 9</bibl>: nam si te tegeret pudor, sive adeo cor sapientia imbutum foret, Pacuv. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 521, 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">mihi adeunda est ratio, quā ad Apronii quaestum, sive adeo, quā ad istius ingentem immanemque praedam possim pervenire,</quote> <trans><tr>or rather</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Verr 2, 3, 46, 110</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:369" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 369</bibl>; so, <hi rend="ital">atque adeo</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ego princeps in adjutoribus atque adeo secundus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:17:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 1, 17, 9</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n754.17" n="6" level="3"> With the <hi rend="ital">imperative</hi>, for emphasis, like <hi rend="ital">tandem</hi>, <hi rend="ital">modo</hi>, <hi rend="ital">dum</hi>, the Germ. <hi rend="ital">so</hi>, and the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">ge\</foreign> (cf. L. and S.), <hi rend="ital">now</hi>, <hi rend="ital">I pray</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">propera adeo puerum tollere hinc ab janua,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:4:4:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 4, 4, 20</bibl></cit> (cf. <foreign lang="greek">culla/bete/ g) au)to/n</foreign>, Soph. Phil. 1003).—</sense><sense id="n754.18" n="C" level="2"> Like <hi rend="ital">admodum</hi> or <hi rend="ital">nimis</hi>, to give emphasis to an idea (for the most part only in comic poets, and never except with the positive of the <pos>adj.</pos>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Consent.</author> 2023</bibl> P.), <hi rend="ital">indeed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">truly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">so very</hi>, <hi rend="ital">so entirely</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nam me ejus spero fratrem propemodum jam repperisse adulescentem adeo nobilem,</quote> <trans><tr>so very noble</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:1:2:123" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 1, 2, 123</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec sum adeo informis,</quote> <trans><tr>nor am I so very ugly</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:2:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 2, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nam Caii Luciique casu non adeo fractus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:65" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 65</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">et merito adeo,</quote> <trans><tr>and with perfect right</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:2:1:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 2, 1, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">etiam num credis te ignorarier aut tua facta adeo,</quote> <trans><tr>do you</tr>, <tr>then</tr>, <tr>think that they are ignorant of you or your conduct entirely?</tr></trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ph. 5, 8, 38</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n754.19" n="D" level="2"> To denote what exceeds expectation, <hi rend="ital">even</hi>: quam omnium Thebis vir unam esse optimam dijudicat, quamque adeo cives Thebani rumificant probam, <hi rend="ital">and whom even the Thebans</hi> (who are always ready to speak evil of others) <hi rend="ital">declare to be an honest woman</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:2:2:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 2, 2, 44</bibl>.— Hence also it denotes something added to the rest of the sentence, <hi rend="ital">besides</hi>, <hi rend="ital">too</hi>, <hi rend="ital">over and above</hi>, usually in the connection: -que adeo (rare, and never in prose; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">adhuc, I.): quin te Di omnes perdant qui me hodie oculis vidisti tuis, meque adeo scelestum,</quote> <trans><tr>and me too</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:4:4:122" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 4, 4, 122</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> 4, 2, 32</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec adeo tibi me, ipsa palam fari omnipotens Saturnia jussit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:427" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 427</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n754.20" n="III" level="1"> After Caesar and Cicero (the only instance of this use adduced from Cicero's works, Off. 1, 11, 36, being found in a passage rejected by the best critics, as B. and K.). </sense><sense id="n754.21" n="A" level="2"> For adding an important and satisfactory reason to an assertion, and then it always stands at the beginning of the clause, <hi rend="ital">indeed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">for</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum Hanno perorāsset, nemini omnium cum eo certare necesse fuit: adeo prope omnis senatus Hannibalis erat: the idea is,</quote> <trans><tr>Hanno's speech</tr>, <tr>though so powerful</tr>, <tr>was ineffectual</tr>, <tr>and did not need a reply; for all the senators belonged to the party of Hannibal</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:11:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 11, 1</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:27:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 27, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:28:2" default="NO" valid="yes">2, 28, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:37:2" default="NO" valid="yes">8, 37, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Tac.</author> Ann. 1, 50, 81</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:3:274" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 3, 274</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:14:233" default="NO">14, 233</bibl>.—Also for introducing a parenthesis: sed ne illi quidem ipsi satis mitem gentem fore (adeo ferocia atque indomita <pb n="34" /> <cb n="ADEQ" /> ingenia esse) ni subinde auro ... principum animi concilientur, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:20:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 20, 8</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:26:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 9, 26, 17</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes">3, 4, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 28</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n754.22" n="B" level="2"> When to a specific fact a general consideration is added as a reason for it, <hi rend="ital">so</hi>, <hi rend="ital">thus</hi> (in Livy very often): <cit><quote lang="la">haud dubius, facilem in aequo campi victoriam fore: adeo non fortuna modo, sed ratio etiam cum barbaris stabat,</quote> <trans><tr>thus not only fortune</tr>, <tr>but sagacity</tr>, <tr>was on the side of the barbarians</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:38:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 38, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adeo ex parvis saepe magnarum momenta rerum pendent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:9:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 27, 9, 1</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:31:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 4, 31, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:33:6" default="NO" valid="yes">21, 33, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:19" default="NO" valid="yes">28, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:12:7" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 12, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:10:2:11" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 10, 2, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adeo in teneris consuescere multum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:272" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 272</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n754.23" n="C" level="2"> In advancing from one thought to another more important = immo, <hi rend="ital">rather</hi>, <hi rend="ital">indeed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">nay</hi>: nulla umquam res publica ubi tantus paupertati ac parsimoniae honos fuerit: adeo, quanto rerum minus, tanto minus cupiditatis erat, Liv. praef. 11; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:11:7" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 11, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Ep. 1:30:37" default="NO"><author>Symm.</author> Ep. 1, 30, 37</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n754.24" n="D" level="2"> With a negative after ne—quidem or quoque, <hi rend="ital">so much the more</hi> or <hi rend="ital">less</hi>, <hi rend="ital">much less than</hi>, <hi rend="ital">still less</hi> (post-Aug.): <cit><quote lang="la">hujus totius temporis fortunam ne deflere quidem satis quisquam digne potuit: adeo nemo exprimere verbis potest,</quote> <trans><tr>still less can one describe: it by words</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:67:1" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 67, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne tecta quidem urbis, adeo publicum consilium numquam adiit,</quote> <trans><tr>still less</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:6:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 6, 15</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 3, 64</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:7:5:35" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 7, 5, 35</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">favore militum anxius et superbia viri aequalium quoque, adeo superiorum intolerantis,</quote> <trans><tr>who could not endure his equals even</tr>, <tr>much less his superiors</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:80" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 4, 80</bibl></cit>.—So in gen., after any negative: quaelibet enim ex iis artibus in paucos libros contrahi solet: adeo infinito spatio ac traditione opus non est, <hi rend="ital">so much the less is there need</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:11:16" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 11, 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:179" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 12, 35, § 179</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 39</bibl>.—(The assumption of a causal signif. of adeo = ideo, propterea, rests upon false readings. For in Cael. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:8:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 8, 15</bibl> we should read <hi rend="ital">ideo</hi>, B. and K., and in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:32:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 24, 32, 6</bibl>, <hi rend="ital">ad ea</hi>, Weiss.).—See more upon this word in Hand, Turs. I. pp. 135-155.</sense></entryFree>
adeona: <entryFree id="n755" type="main" key="A^de^o_na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ădĕōna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n755.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the tutelary goddess of new-comers</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Civ. D. 4:21" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Civ. D. 4, 21</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adeps: <entryFree id="n756" type="main" key="a^deps"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădeps</orth>, <itype>ĭpis</itype>, <gen>comm.</gen> (in Plin. and Serv., <gen>m.</gen>; in Cels., Quint., and Pallad., <gen>f.</gen>; in Col. <sense id="n756.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">c.;</hi> cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 657</bibl> and 752 P.; Rudd. I. p. 34; Koffm. s. v.) [from <foreign lang="greek">a)/leifa</foreign> with interch. of <hi rend="ital">d</hi> and <hi rend="ital">l</hi>], <hi rend="ital">the soft fat</hi> or <hi rend="ital">grease of animals</hi>, <hi rend="ital">suet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">lard</hi> (the hard is called <hi rend="ital">sevum</hi>). </sense><sense id="n756.1" n="A" level="2"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">suilla,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:11:7" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 11, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ursinus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:28:163" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 28, 11, 46, § 163</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vulpinus, ib.: anserinus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 48</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">caprina,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:R. R. 6:12:5" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> R. R. 6, 12, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad creandas adipes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:ib. 8:14:11" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 8, 14, 11</bibl></cit>. —And in the sense of <hi rend="ital">sevum</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adipe, qui prope omnes Italas lucernas illuminat,</quote> <trans><tr>the tallow</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:de Mor. Manich. 2:16" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> de Mor. Manich. 2, 16</bibl></cit>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n756.2" n="B" level="2"> Metaph. </sense><sense id="n756.3" n="1" level="3"> Of men: non mihi esse Lentuli somnum, nec Cassii adipes, nec Cethegi temeritatem pertimescendam, <hi rend="ital">the corpulence</hi>, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:3:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 3, 7</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">dum sciat (declamator) sibi quoque tenuandas adipes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:10:6" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 10, 6</bibl></cit> (v. adipatus, crassus, crassedo).—</sense><sense id="n756.4" n="2" level="3"> Of fat or fertile earth, <hi rend="ital">marl</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 6, 4, § 42</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n756.5" n="3" level="3"> In trees, <hi rend="ital">that part of the wood which is soft and full of sap</hi>, also called <hi rend="ital">alburnum</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:182" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 38, 72, § 182</bibl>.!*? The form <hi rend="ital">adipes</hi>, assumed by <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 752</bibl> and 1293 P., on account of <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:11" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 11</bibl>, rests upon an error, since not <hi rend="ital">adipes illa</hi>, but <hi rend="ital">adeps suilla</hi>, should be read there, v. Schneid. ad h. l.</sense></entryFree>
adeptio: <entryFree id="n757" type="main" key="a^depti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădeptĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>adipiscor</etym>, <sense id="n757.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an obtaining</hi>, <hi rend="ital">attainment</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nos beatam vitam non depulsione mali, sed adeptione boni judicemus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:13:41" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 13, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bonorum (opp., malorum evitatio),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:5:10:33" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 5, 10, 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alicujus commodi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,038:32:113" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Part. Or. 32, 113</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adeptus: <entryFree id="n758" type="main" key="a^deptus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădeptus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of adipiscor.</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n759" type="hapax" key="a^deptus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădeptus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = adeptio, <sense id="n759.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an obtaining</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">fidei,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul. Nol.</author> Ep. 32, 18</bibl></cit> (in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:3:14:48" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 3, 14, 48</bibl>, Henry Stephens reads: ad virtutis adeptum, but the true reading is <hi rend="ital">habitum</hi>, Madv.).</sense></entryFree>
adequito: <entryFree id="n760" type="main" key="a^de^qui^to"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-ĕquĭto</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> <sense id="n760.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To ride to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">toward</hi> a place, <hi rend="ital">to gallop up to.</hi>—With <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>: equites Ariovisti propius tumulum accedere et ad nostros adequitare, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 46</bibl>.—With <hi rend="ital">in</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in primos ordines,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:7:4:17" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 7, 4, 17</bibl></cit>.—With the local <hi rend="ital">adv. quo</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quo tam ferociter adequitāsset, inde se fundi fugarique,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:22:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 9, 22, 6</bibl></cit>. —With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">portis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:42:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 22, 42, 5</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">portae Collinae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 18, 20, § 76</bibl></cit>: vallo, Liv. <cb n="ADHA" /> 9, 22, 4: <cit><quote lang="la">castris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:6:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 6, 34</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">acc. of limit</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adequitare Syracusas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 24, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">perarmatos adequitare coepit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:9:14" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 9, 14</bibl></cit> (Vogel now reads here <hi rend="ital">ad perarmatos</hi>).— </sense><sense id="n760.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To ride near to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">by</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">juxta aliquem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Cal. 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vehiculo anteire aut circa adequitare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:64" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Aug. 64</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aderro: <entryFree id="n761" type="main" key="a^derro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-erro</orth>, <itype>āre, 1</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, <sense id="n761.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to wander to.</hi>— With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">scopulis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:2:2:120" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 2, 2, 120</bibl></cit>.— <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">ululatus aderrat auribus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:9:178" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 9, 178</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adesco: <entryFree id="n762" type="hapax" key="a^desco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-esco</orth>, <itype>āre, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n762.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to feed</hi> or <hi rend="ital">fatten</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">volantia adescata,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Acut. 1:11" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Acut. 1, 11</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adesdum: <entryFree id="n763" type="hapax" key="a^desdum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădesdum</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">ădes dum</orth> (imper. from adsum with dum; cf.: agedum, manedum, etc., v. dum), <sense id="n763.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">come hither</hi>: Sosia, adesdum; <cit><quote lang="la">paucis te volo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 1, 2</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adesurio: <entryFree id="n764" type="hapax" key="a^de_su^ri^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-ēsŭrĭo</orth>, <itype>īvi, 4</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> <etym>ad, <hi rend="ital">intens.</hi></etym>, <sense id="n764.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to be very hungry</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adesurivit et inhiavit acrius lupus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1:2:132" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 1, 2, 132</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adesus: <entryFree id="n765" type="main" key="a^de_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădēsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, v. <itype>adedo</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos></entryFree>
adexpeto: <entryFree id="n766" type="spur" key="a^dexpe^to"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-expĕto</orth>, <itype>ĕre</itype>, false read. in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 117:4" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 117, 4</bibl>.</entryFree>
adf: <entryFree id="n767" type="main" key="adf"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adf</orth>. Words beginning thus, v. under aff.</entryFree>
adg: <entryFree id="n768" type="main" key="adg"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adg</orth>. Words beginning thus, v. under agg.</entryFree>
adhabito: <entryFree id="n769" type="spur" key="a^dha^bi^to"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-hăbĭto</orth>, <itype>āre, 1</itype>, <sense id="n769.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. n.</hi>: adhabites, a false reading for <hi rend="ital">adbites</hi> in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:3:4:72" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 3, 4, 72</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adhaereo: <entryFree id="n770" type="main" key="a^dhaere^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-haerĕo</orth>, <itype>haesi, haesum, 2</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, <sense id="n770.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to cleave</hi> or <hi rend="ital">stick to</hi> a thing. </sense><sense id="n770.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, of iron adhering to a magnet: <cit><quote lang="la">unus ubi ex uno dependet, subter adhaerens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:914" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 914</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:557" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 557</bibl>: tota adhaerens (lingua) crocodilis, <hi rend="ital">cleaving to</hi> his palate, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:171" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 37, 65, § 171</bibl>.—With <hi rend="ital">in</hi> and <case>abl.</case>: <cit><quote lang="la">tela in tuis visceribus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,023:5:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Vatin. 5, 13</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:693" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 693</bibl>.—With <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cratera et corvus adhaeret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,060:chapter=541" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Arat. 541</bibl></cit> (so Tert.: humerum, de <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 5</bibl>).—With <case>abl.</case>: <cit><quote lang="la">fronte cuspis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:5:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 5, 38</bibl></cit>.—With <case>dat.</case>, <usg type="style">poet.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">tonsis (ovibus) illotus sudor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:443" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 443</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">veteri craterae limus adhaesit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Sat. 2, 4, 80</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">and in later prose: navis ancoris,</quote> <trans><tr>is fastened to them</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">stativis castris,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 21</bibl></cit>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">jumento,</quote> <trans><tr>to stick to</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:20:1" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 20, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n770.2" n="II" level="1"> Fig. </sense><sense id="n770.3" n="A" level="2"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">to cling to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">adhere to</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adhaesit homini ad intimum ventrem fames,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:1:3:83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 1, 3, 83</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">and of fawning adherence to one,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:1:3:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> As. 1, 3, 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cui canis ex vero dictum cognomen adhaeret,</quote> <trans><tr>adheres</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:2:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 2, 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nulli fortunae adhaerebat animus, i. e. inconstans fuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:41:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 41, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obsidioni fortiter adhaerentes,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 19, 3</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n770.4" n="B" level="2"> Adhaerere alicui, <hi rend="ital">to be close to a person</hi> or <hi rend="ital">thing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be near</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to hang on</hi>, <hi rend="ital">keep close to</hi>, etc. (mostly post-Cic., esp. in the histt.): <cit><quote lang="la">vineis modica silva adhaerebat,</quote> <trans><tr>was close to it</tr>, <tr>adjoined it</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 25</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 18, 2</bibl>.—Of persons: procul abesse Romanos: lateri adhaerere gravem dominum, i. e. <hi rend="ital">he</hi> (the King of Macedon) <hi rend="ital">hangs on them</hi>, <hi rend="ital">threatens them by his nearness</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 39, 25</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec umquam non adhaerentes,</quote> <trans><tr>and never departing from his side</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=gal.:14" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Galb. 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">comitem perpetuo alicui adhaerere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 22, 26, § 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tempus adhaerens,</quote> <trans><tr>the time in hand</tr>, <tr>just the present time</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:5:10:46" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 5, 10, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obvio quoque adhaerente,</quote> <trans><tr>while each one adhered to him</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=otho:6" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Oth. 6</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">and so trop.: adhaeret altissimis invidia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:1:9" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 1, 9</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n770.5" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To hang on</hi> a thing, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to trail</hi> or <hi rend="ital">drag after</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be the last</hi>, sarcastically in Cic.: tenesne memoriā te extremum adhaesisse? <hi rend="ital">hung on the end</hi>, i. e. extremo loco quaestorem esse factum, Vat. 5 (cf. haerere, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 2 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>, and Gron. ad h. l.); <cit><quote lang="la">and without sarcasm,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:10:5:19" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 10, 5, 19</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adhaeresco: <entryFree id="n771" type="main" key="a^dhaeresco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-haeresco</orth>, <itype>haesi, haesum, 3</itype>, <sense id="n771.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. inch.</hi> [adhaereo], <hi rend="ital">to cleave</hi> or <hi rend="ital">stick to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to adhere</hi>, lit. and trop. (in the trop. sense almost exclusively belonging to Cic.). </sense><sense id="n771.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, constr. with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in</hi>, and <case>abl.</case> or <hi rend="ital">ubi</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tragula ad turrim,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne quid emineret, ubi ignis adhaeresceret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. C. 2, 9</bibl></cit>: tamquam in quodam incili, Cael. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:8:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 8, 5</bibl>: si potes in his locis adhaerescere, <hi rend="ital">if you can stick</hi> (i. e. <hi rend="ital">stay</hi> or <hi rend="ital">sojourn</hi>) <hi rend="ital">in such places</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:4:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 4, 4</bibl>: in me omnia conjurationis nefaria tela adhaeserunt, Auct. Or. pro Dom. 24; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 5</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">ad quamcunque disciplinam, tamquam ad saxum, adhaerescunt,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 3</bibl></cit>: argumentum ratio ipsa confirmat, quae simul atque emissa est, adhaerescit, sc. ad mentem,<cb n="ADHI" />  <hi rend="ital">sticks fast to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">is fastened upon the memory</hi> (the figure is derived from missiles), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 53</bibl>.—With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: justitiae honestatique, <hi rend="ital">to be attached</hi> or <hi rend="ital">devoted to</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:24" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 24</bibl>.—And <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">oratio ita libere fluebat, ut numquam adhaeresceret,</quote> <trans><tr>never was at a stand</tr>, <tr>faltered</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=79" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 79</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 93</bibl> (v. haereo): adhaerescere ad columnam (sc. Maeniam); sarcastically, <hi rend="ital">to remain fixed at the debtor's columns</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to be punished as a fraudulent debtor</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:8:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 8, 18</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 47</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n771.2" n="II" level="1"> Fig., <hi rend="ital">to correspond to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to accord with</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to fit to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">suit</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si non omnia, quae praeponerentur a me ad omnium vestrūm studium, adhaerescerent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:10:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 10, 37</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adhaese: <entryFree id="n772" type="hapax" key="a^dhaese"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădhaese</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>adhaereo</etym>, <sense id="n772.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">hesitatingly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">stammeringly</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">loqui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:5:9" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 5, 9</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adhaesio: <entryFree id="n773" type="hapax" key="a^dhaesi^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădhaesĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>adhaereo</etym>, <sense id="n773.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an adhering</hi>, <hi rend="ital">adhesion</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">complexiones et copulationes et adhaesiones atomorum inter se,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:6:19" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 1, 6, 19</bibl></cit>, v. Madv. ad h. l.; Gloss. <bibl default="NO"><author>Placid.</author> Clas. Auct. III. p. 427</bibl> Mai.</sense></entryFree>
adhaesus: <entryFree id="n774" type="main" key="a^dhaesus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădhaesus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n774.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an adhering</hi>, <hi rend="ital">adherence</hi> (only in Lucr.): <cit><quote lang="la">pulveris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 38</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:1242" default="NO" valid="yes">4, 1242</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">membrorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:842" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 842</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">umoris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:472" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 6, 472</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 73, 6</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adhalo: <entryFree id="n775" type="hapax" key="a^dha_lo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-hālo</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n775.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to breathe on</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si patescentes (fungos) primo (serpens) adhalaverit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:22:95" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 22, 22, 46, § 95</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adhamo: <entryFree id="n776" type="main" key="a^dha_mo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădhāmo</orth>, <itype>āre, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>hamus</etym>, <sense id="n776.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to catch</hi>, <hi rend="ital">secure</hi>: Qui serius honores adhamaverunt, vix admittuntur ad eos, Cic. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 2, 5</bibl>, where Mercer. better reads <hi rend="ital">adamaverunt.</hi></sense></entryFree>
adherbal: <entryFree id="n777" type="main" key="Adherbal"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Adherbal</orth>, <itype>ălis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n777.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Numidian prince</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the son of Micipsa</hi>, <hi rend="ital">slain by Jugurtha</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 5 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 5 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
adhibeo: <entryFree id="n778" type="main" key="a^dhi^be^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-hĭbĕo</orth>, <itype>ŭi, ĭtum, 2</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>habeo</etym>, <sense id="n778.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to hold toward</hi> or <hi rend="ital">to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to turn</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bring</hi>, <hi rend="ital">add to;</hi> with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in</hi>, <case>dat.</case> or <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> </sense><sense id="n778.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen. </sense><sense id="n778.2" n="A" level="2"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">cur non adhibuisti, dum istaec loquereris, tympanum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:5:5:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 5, 5, 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">huc adhibete aurīs (ad ea) quae ego loquar,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:2:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 1, 2, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad mea formosos vultus adhibete carmina,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:2:1:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 2, 1, 37</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 13, 15</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">manus medicas ad vulnera,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:455" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 455</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">odores ad deos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:40" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quos negat ad panem adhibere quidquam, praeter nasturtium,</quote> <trans><tr>to eat with it</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:34" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alicui calcaria,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=56" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 56</bibl></cit> (cf. addere calcar, v. addo): <cit><quote lang="la">manus genibus adhibet, i. e. admovet, genua amplexatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:216" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 9, 216</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vincula captis,</quote> <trans><tr>to put them on them</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:3:293" default="NO"><author>id.</author> F. 3, 293</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n778.3" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">metum ut mihi adhibeam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:5:6:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 5, 6, 20</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:3:15" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 3, 15</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc animum nobis adhibe veram ad rationem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:1023" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 1023</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,021:10:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Har. Resp. 10, 20</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">vacuas aurīs adhibe ad veram rationem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 51</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:238" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 238</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:315" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 315</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut oratio, quae lumen adhibere rebus debet, ea obscuritatem afferat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:13:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 13, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">est ea (oratio) quidem utilior, sed raro proficit neque est ad vulgus adhibenda,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:28:60" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 4, 28, 60</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adhibere cultus, honores, preces, diis immortalibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 1, 2</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:14:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 14, 53</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">alicui voluptates,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:chapter=35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mur. 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">consolationem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=96" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 96</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnes ii motus, quos orator adhibere volet judici,</quote> <trans><tr>which the orator may wish to communicate to the judge</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:45 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 45 al.</bibl></cit>—Hence = addere, adjungere, <hi rend="ital">to add to</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">uti quattuor initiis rerum illis quintam hanc naturam non adhiberet,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 1, 11, 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad domesticorum majorumque morem etiam hanc a Socrate adventitiam doctrinam adhibuerunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:3:3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 3, 3</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n778.4" n="II" level="1"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n778.5" n="A" level="2"> Of persons, <hi rend="ital">to bring one to</hi> a place, <hi rend="ital">to summon</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to employ</hi> (cf. the Engl. <hi rend="ital">to have one up</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">hoc temere numquam amittam ego a me, quin mihi testes adhibeam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ter.</author> Ph. 4, 5, 2</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:21" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 21</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 14</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">medicum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,054:chapter=12" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fat. 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">leges, ad quas (sc. defendendas) adhibemur,</quote> <trans><tr>we are summoned</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 52</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec, quoniam apud Graecos judices res agetur, poteris adhibere Demosthenem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:5:10" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 5, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adhibebitur heros,</quote> <trans><tr>shall be brought upon the stage</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:227" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 227</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">castris adhibere socios et foedera jungere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem in partem periculi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:11:447" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 11, 447</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in auxilium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:3:6" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 3, 6</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n778.6" n="B" level="2"> Adhibere ad or in consilium, <hi rend="ital">to send for one in order to receive counsel from him</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to consult one</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque hos ad concilium adhibendos censeo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:77:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 77, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in consilium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:6:11:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 6, 11, 1</bibl></cit>; so also <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">a tuis reliquis non adhibemur,</quote> <trans><tr>we are not consulted</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:4:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 4, 7</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 10, 25</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">11</bibl>, <pb n="35" /> <cb n="ADHO" /> 7; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:20" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:5:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 5, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:35" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 35</bibl>; cf. Cortius ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 113" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 113</bibl>, and ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:4:7:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 4, 7, 15</bibl>.—But sometimes adhibere in consilium = admittere in cons., <hi rend="ital">to admit to a consultation.</hi> —So trop.: <cit><quote lang="la">est tuum, sic agitare animo, ut non adhibeas in consilium cogitationum tuarum desperationem aut timorem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 6, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n778.7" n="C" level="2"> Adhibere aliquem cenae, epulis, etc., <hi rend="ital">to invite to a dinner</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to a banquet</hi>, etc., <hi rend="ital">to entertain</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adhibete Penatīs et patrios epulis, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 62</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:5:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 5, 32</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:73" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 73</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:74" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> 74</bibl>: in convivium, Nep. praef. 7.—And <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to receive</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to treat</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quos ego universos adhiberi liberaliter dico oportere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 1, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quintum filium severius adhibebo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:10:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 10, 12</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n778.8" n="D" level="2"> Adhibere se ad aliquid, <hi rend="ital">to betake</hi> or <hi rend="ital">apply one's self to a thing</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to devote attention to it</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adhibere se remotum a curis veram ad rationem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 44</bibl></cit> (cf. above I. A.); and <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>: adhibere se, <hi rend="ital">to appear</hi> or <hi rend="ital">to behave one's self</hi> in any manner: <cit><quote lang="la">permagni est hominis, sic se adhibere in tanta potestate, ut nulla alia potestas ab iis, quibus ipse praeest, desideretur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:1:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 1, 1, 7</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n778.9" n="E" level="2"> Adhibere aliquid ad aliquid, alicui rei, or with <hi rend="ital">in</hi> and <case>abl.</case>, <hi rend="ital">to put a thing to a determinate use</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to apply</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to use</hi> or <hi rend="ital">employ for</hi> or <hi rend="ital">in any thing definite</hi> (therefore, with intention and deliberation; on the contr., <hi rend="ital">usurpare</hi> denotes merely momentary use; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:2:8" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 2, 8</bibl>; and <hi rend="ital">uti</hi>, use that arises from some necessity, Herz. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 20</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">adhibere omnem diligentiam ad convalescendum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:16:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 16, 9</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 21</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cautionem privatis rebus suis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 1, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">medicinam aegroto,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 16, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">humatis titulum, i. e. inscriptionem addere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">belli necessitatibus patientiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fraudem testamento,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=dom.:2" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Dom. 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">curam viis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=vesp.:5" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Vesp. 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fidem et diligentiam in amicorum periculis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:42:118" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 42, 118</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">misericordiam in fortunis alicujus et sapientiam in salute reip.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,012:chapter=2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rab. Perd. 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">flores in causis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:chapter=19" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">curam in valetudine tuenda,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:3:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 3, 18</bibl></cit>; and with <hi rend="ital">de</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">curam de aliqua re,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:7:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 2, 7, 3</bibl></cit>: modum, <hi rend="ital">to set a limit to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to set bounds to</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">vitio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:17" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sumptibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:16" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 16</bibl></cit>: cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:100" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Aug. 100</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:34" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tib. 34</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">voluptati,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:3:74" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 9, 3, 74</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">memoriam contumeliae,</quote> <trans><tr>to retain it in memory</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Epam. 7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Epam. 7</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n778.10" n="F" level="1"> Adhibere aliquid, in gen., <hi rend="ital">to use</hi>, <hi rend="ital">employ</hi>, <hi rend="ital">exercise</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque quisquam parsimoniam adhibet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:1:3:79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 1, 3, 79</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fidem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:4:3:104" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 4, 3, 104</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">celeritatem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:10:21:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 10, 21, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">calumniam, fraudem, dolum, id. Auct. Or. pro Dom. 14, 36: modum quemdam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:17:38" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 17, 38</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:2" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nulla arte adhibita,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sollertiam, Tibull. 3, 4, 75: querelas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:1:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 1, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adhibere moram = differre,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1321,001:Dig. 18:6:16" default="NO"><author>Pompon.</author> Dig. 18, 6, 16</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n778.11" n="G" level="1"> In later Lat.: alicui aliquem, <hi rend="ital">to bring up</hi>, <hi rend="ital">quote one to another as authority for an assertion</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">is nos aquam multam ex diluta nive bibentis coërcebat, severiusque increpabat adhibebatque nobis auctoritates nobilium medicorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:19:5:3" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 19, 5, 3</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adhibitio: <entryFree id="n779" type="main" key="a^dhi^bi^ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădhĭbĭtĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>adhibeo</etym> (late Lat.). <sense id="n779.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An admission</hi> (cf. adhibeo, II. C.): <cit><quote lang="la">convivii,</quote> <trans><tr>to a banquet</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1251,001:Inst. 1:1" default="NO"><author>Gai.</author> Inst. 1, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n779.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An employing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">application</hi> (cf. ib. II. F.): <cit><quote lang="la">cucurbitarum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Marc. Emp.</author> 15</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adhibitus: <entryFree id="n780" type="main" key="a^dhi^bi^tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădhĭbĭtus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of adhibeo.</entryFree>
adhinnio: <entryFree id="n781" type="main" key="a^dhinni^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-hinnĭo</orth>, <itype>īvi, or ĭi, ītum, 4</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, <sense id="n781.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to neigh to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">after.</hi> </sense><sense id="n781.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, constr. with <case>dat.</case> and <case>acc.</case>, also <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> and <hi rend="ital">in</hi> with <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">fortis equus visae semper adhinnit equae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Rem. Am. 634</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:1:208" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. A. 1, 208</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:95" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 10, 36, § 95</bibl>.—Hence, of lewd persons, Plaut. Fragm. ap. Mai. p. 19; Prud. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:1:57" default="NO"><author>Symm.</author> 1, 57</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>August.</author> de Mor. Manich. 2, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in aliquam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 4, p. 135</bibl></cit>: so, <cit><quote lang="la">ad aliquam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,049:5:8 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Jer. 5, 8 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n781.2" n="II" level="1"> Fig., <hi rend="ital">to strive after</hi> or <hi rend="ital">long for with voluptuous desire</hi>: admissarius iste ad illius orationem adhinnivit, <hi rend="ital">gave his passionate assent to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">expressed his delight in</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:28:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 28, 69</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">virginis delicatas voculas,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 6, p. 185</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adhorreo: <entryFree id="n782" type="spur" key="a^dhorre^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-horrĕo</orth>, <itype>ēre</itype>, a false read. in Albinov. 1, 221, for <sense id="n782.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">inhorreo.</hi></sense></entryFree>
adhortamen: <entryFree id="n783" type="hapax" key="a^dhorta_men"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădhortāmen</orth>, <itype>ĭnis</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>adhortor</etym>, <sense id="n783.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a means of exhortation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an exhortation</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">multa mihi apud vos adhortamina suppetunt,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Flor. 4, 18, p. 359</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adhortatio: <entryFree id="n784" type="main" key="a^dhorta_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădhortātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n784.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an exhortation</hi>,<cb n="ADHU" />  <hi rend="ital">encouragement</hi> (class.): omissa nostra adhortatione veniamus ad eorum sermonem, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:3:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 3, 11</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum clamore comprobata adhortatio esset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 38</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:13" default="NO" valid="yes">9, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:3:11:9" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 3, 11, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:159" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 42, 65, § 159</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:3:64" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 11, 3, 64</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:94 al" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 94 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
adhortativus: <entryFree id="n785" type="main" key="a^dhorta_ti_vus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădhortātīvus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>adhortor</etym>, <sense id="n785.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">belonging to exhortation</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">modus,</quote> <trans><tr>the mood of</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> I. p. 328</bibl></cit> P. al.</sense></entryFree>
adhortator: <entryFree id="n786" type="main" key="a^dhorta_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădhortātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n786.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an exhorter</hi>, <hi rend="ital">encourager</hi>, <hi rend="ital">exciter</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">operis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 58</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 7, 32</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:13" default="NO" valid="yes">9, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:32:25" default="NO" valid="yes">32, 25</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adhortatus: <entryFree id="n787" type="main" key="a^dhorta_tus" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădhortātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of adhortor.<sense id="n787.0" n="2" level="3"> * <orth extent="full" lang="la">ădhortātus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>adhortor</etym>, <hi rend="ital">an exhortation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">persuasion</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">meo adhortatu,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Mag. p. 338</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adhortor: <entryFree id="n788" type="main" key="a^dhortor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-hortor</orth>, <itype>āri, ātus, 1</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos>, <sense id="n788.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to encourage</hi>, <hi rend="ital">urge</hi>, <hi rend="ital">exhort one to</hi> a thing, constr. with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in</hi>, <hi rend="ital">de</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nam me meae vitae consuetudo ad C. Rabirium defendendum est adhortata,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,012:chapter=1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rab. Perd. 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne posset aliquando ad bellum faciendum locus ipse adhortari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:11:35" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 11, 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem ad certam laudem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 1, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">loricatos ad discumbendum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:45" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in bellum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 61</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in ultionem sui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:41" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">de re frumentaria Boios atque Aeduos adhortari non destitit,</quote> <trans><tr>he did not cease to incite and spur on the Boii and Aedui</tr>, <tr>in respect to a supply of corn</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 17</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">milites,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:4:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 4, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nullo adhortante sibi quisque dux et instigator,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 38</bibl></cit>.—Followed by <hi rend="ital">ut</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ne</hi>, or the simple <hi rend="ital">subj.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adhort. adulescentes, ut turbulenti velint esse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 1, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tandem Bruto adhortante, ne jamdudum operientes destitueret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:81" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 81</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adhortor, properent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:3:5:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 3, 5, 35</bibl></cit>: adhortari se, <hi rend="ital">to rouse</hi> or <hi rend="ital">bestir one's self</hi>: ferus ipse (leo) sese adhortans rapidum incitat animo, Catull. 63, 85.!*? Pass.: adulati erant ab amicis et adhortati, Cassius ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 791</bibl> P.: punctione aliqua adhortati vel titillati, Cael. Aurel. Acut. 2, 3.</sense></entryFree>
adhospito: <entryFree id="n789" type="main" key="a^dhospi^to"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-hospĭto</orth>, <itype>āvi</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n789.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to entertain as guest.</hi>—Only trop.: <cit><quote lang="la">Martem atque Concordiam multis immolationibus sibi adhospitavere,</quote> <trans><tr>to propitiate</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Dict. Cret.</author> 1, 15 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
adhuc: <entryFree id="n790" type="main" key="a^dhuc"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-huc</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> <sense id="n790.0" n="I" level="1"> Prop., of place, <hi rend="ital">to this place</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hitherto</hi>, <hi rend="ital">thus far</hi> (designating the limit, inclusive of the whole space traversed: hence often joined with usque; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">ad, A. 1. B.): conveniunt adhuc utriusque verba,</quote> <trans><tr>thus far</tr>, <tr>to this point</tr>, <tr>the statements of both agree</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:4:3:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 4, 3, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adhuc ea dixi, causa cur Zenoni non fuisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:4:16:44" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 4, 16, 44</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 1, 9, 16</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">his oris, quas angulo Baeticae adhuc usque perstrinximus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:3:6:1" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 3, 6, 1</bibl></cit>.—Hence, in the desig. of measure or degree, <hi rend="ital">so far</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to such a degree</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">et ipse Caesar erat adhuc impudens, qui exercitum et provinciam invito senatu teneret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:16:11:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 16, 11, 4</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:18:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 18, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:19:2" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 19, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:5:20" default="NO">8, 5, 20</bibl>.—More frequently,</sense><sense id="n790.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n790.2" n="A" level="2"> Of time, <hi rend="ital">until now</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hitherto</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as yet</hi> (designating the limit, together with the period already passed; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">ad, 1. B.): res adhuc quidem hercle in tuto est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:2:3:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. 2, 3, 48</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">celabitur itidem ut celata adhuc est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:4:3:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 4, 3, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sicut adhuc fecerunt, speculabuntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 1, 2, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ille vidit non modo, quot fuissent adhuc philosophorum de summo bono, sed quot omnino esse possent sententiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:6:16" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 5, 6, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec adhuc (sc. acta sunt): sed ad praeterita revertamur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 5, 20</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 3, 14 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 17, 46</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:3:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Agr. 3, 1, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Britanni, qui adhuc pugnae expertes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 37</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:7:7:8 al" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 7, 7, 8 al.</bibl>—With <hi rend="ital">usque</hi> or <hi rend="ital">semper</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">usque adhuc actum est probe,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:2:6:107" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 2, 6, 107</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:4:7:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 4, 7, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:5:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 5, 27</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:4:4:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ad. 4, 4, 23</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 4, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:4:1:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Hec. 4, 1, 29</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:20" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 2, 20</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod adhuc semper tacui et tacendum putavi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:26:119" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 26, 119</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">dum</hi> in subordinate propositions, for the purpose of more accurate desig. of time: <cit><quote lang="la">quae adhuc te carens, dum hic fui, sustentabam,</quote> <trans><tr>what I have endured during the whole time that I have been here</tr>, <tr>until now</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:5:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 5, 1, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adhuc dum mihi nullo loco deesse vis, numquam te confirmare potuisti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:16:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 16, 4</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 18</bibl>.—Hence the adverbial expression (occurring once in Plautus): adhuc locorum, <hi rend="ital">until now</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hitherto</hi>: ut adhuc locorum feci, faciam sedulo, Capt. 2, 3, 25.— <cb n="ADHU" /> Adhuc denotes not merely a limitation of time in the present, but also, though more rarely, like <hi rend="ital">usque eo</hi> and <hi rend="ital">ad id tempus</hi>, and the Engl. <hi rend="ital">as yet</hi>, in the past: <cit><quote lang="la">adhuc haec erant, ad reliqua alacri tendebamus animo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:2:4" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 2, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Abraham vero adhuc stabat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:18:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 18, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">unam adhuc a te epistulam acceperam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum adhuc sustinuisset multos dies,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:18:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Act. 18, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">scripsi etiam illud quodam in libello ... disertos me cognōsse nonnullos, eloquentem adhuc neminem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">una adhuc victoria Carus Metius censebatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 45</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n790.3" n="B" level="2"> Adhuc non, or neque adhuc, <hi rend="ital">not as yet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">not to this time</hi>: nihil adhuc, <hi rend="ital">nothing as yet</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">not at all as yet</hi>: numquam adhuc, <hi rend="ital">never as yet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">never yet</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cupidissimi veniendi maximis injuriis affecti, adhuc non venerunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:27:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 27, 65</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">me adhuc non legisse turpe utrique nostrum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:24:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 7, 24, 7</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> 3, 8, 25</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">6, 14</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">14, 6, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:7:89:10" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 7, 89, 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cui neque fulgor adhuc nec dum sua forma recessit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 70</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil adhuc peccavit etiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:4:4:78" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 4, 4, 78</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil adhuc est, quod vereare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:1:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 1, 2, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed quod quaeris, quando, qua, quo, nihil adhuc scimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:7:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 7, 4</bibl></cit>; so 9, 17, 7; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 57</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Milt. 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">numquam etiam quicquam adhuc verborum est prolocutus perperam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:92" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 92</bibl></cit>;
